title: Ofsted‚Äôs gargantuan framework will cause conflict and achieve little | Letters
description: Frank Coffield offers an alternative way forward. Plus a letter from Chris Dunne
content:
Ofsted is incapable of reforming itself. It has rejected the advice calling for radical change (Ofsted to press ahead with new inspection regime despite opposition, 9 September). The new toolkit runs to 80 pages and lists 314 standards over seven areas that institutions will be judged on. It‚Äôs like deciding to repaint the Titanic after it‚Äôs hit the iceberg.

Anger is mounting about the opportunity being lost to create a humane and effective system of inspection. If the government accepts Ofsted‚Äôs gargantuan framework, the coming months will be consumed by conflict with the professionals.

There‚Äôs an alternative way forward. Ministers should set up a commission of teachers‚Äô leaders, experienced inspectors and experts in inspection to produce a different model. It would support teachers to improve the quality of students‚Äô learning, while dealing firmly, but sensitively, with the weaknesses that undeniably exist.

Why not test whatever model the government chooses by running alongside it a pilot of the best ideas on inspection, culled from national and international research? The pilot could take place in an area chosen to be as representative as possible of the country as a whole. Whatever system proved to be the more effective could become the makings of a new evidence-based approach.

The opportunity to enact reform comes round seldom. This one must be seized with both hands to end the decades of failure to raise standards. Will the government rise to the occasion and transform inspection for good? Over to you, Bridget Phillipson.
Frank Coffield
Emeritus professor of education, UCL Institute of Education

‚Ä¢ When the secondary school that I led was first inspected by Ofsted in 1997 it involved 16 inspectors spending the best part of a week in school, going everywhere and seeing everything they needed to. The outcome report, though it pulled no punches, was thorough and largely accurate and provided a sound basis for our own development plan. Long before I retired, an inspection involved a mere four inspectors and lasted barely two days, with oral ‚Äúfeedback‚Äù, such as it was, being given after lunch on the second day.

Martyn Oliver, the chief inspector, says Ofsted‚Äôs new traffic light report card will give parents the information they deserve and ensure that the work of education professionals is fairly assessed. The sad truth is that, like the one it replaces, this report will be done on the cheap and provide the very flimsiest of evidence on which parents or professionals could base any worthwhile judgments. Even worse, it will continue to be used punitively in judging headteachers and their staff and do nothing to relieve the unrealistic pressures, which see nearly a third of newly qualified teachers leave the profession within five years.
Chris Dunne
London

title: Precious gold samples stolen in raid on French natural history museum
description: Museum says specimens taken are worth ‚Ç¨600,000 based on price of gold but have ‚Äòimmeasurable heritage value‚Äô
content:
Historic gold samples with a street value of ‚Ç¨600,000 but priceless to scientists and researchers have been stolen from the French national natural history museum in the latest of a series of museum robberies in France.

‚ÄúThis has happened in a critical context for cultural establishments in France, particularly museums,‚Äù the Paris museum said. ‚ÄúSeveral public collections have been the victims of robberies in the past months.‚Äù

In the early hours of Tuesday morning, an apparently well-planned criminal operation targeted the museum‚Äôs geology and mineralogy gallery. Cleaning staff detected the break-in later that day and museum teams saw that four to six pieces of gold were missing.

The thieves are believed to have used an angle grinder and blowtorch to force their way into the riverside museum that sits on the edge of Paris‚Äôs Jardin des Plantes. It is an unprecedented theft from the high-security museum.

A museum spokesperson said thieves took ‚Äúseveral specimens of native gold from the national collections held by the museum‚Äù. The spokesperson added: ‚ÄúWhile the stolen specimens are valued at around ‚Ç¨600,000 based on the price of raw gold, they nevertheless carry an immeasurable heritage value. The museum laments this inestimable loss for research, heritage and for a collection accessible to the public.‚Äù

Native gold is a metal alloy containing gold and silver in their natural, unrefined form.

The museum‚Äôs director, Emmanuel Skoulios, told BFMTV: ‚ÄúWe are dealing with an extremely professional team, perfectly aware of where they needed to go, and with professional equipment. It is absolutely not by chance that they went for these specific items. Beyond the material value, for the museum this is above all about pieces in the national collection whose historic, scientific and heritage value is incalculable.‚Äù

The museum‚Äôs mineralogy gallery remained closed on Wednesday while the organised crime unit of Paris‚Äôs judicial police led an investigation. Security was increased at the museum and staff were checking the collection for other losses.

One of the museum‚Äôs treasures, according to its website, is a native gold and quartz sample measuring 9cm by 8.5cm that originated in the Donatia mine in California and was donated by a wealthy French collector.

Earlier this month the Adrien-Dubouch√© National Museum in Limoges, central France, was broken into and thieves took three objects worth a total of more than ‚Ç¨6.5m and classed as ‚Äúnational treasures‚Äù in France. They were two 14th- and 15th-century China porcelain plates and an 18th-century China porcelain vase.

The mayor of Limoges, √âmile Roger Lombertie, told Agence France-Presse on the day the robbery was discovered: ‚ÄúCriminality is increasing, we always have to be one step ahead. All the great museums of the world have had pieces stolen at one time or another. It is seemingly collectors giving orders to established criminal gangs.‚Äù

Last November, four men with axes and baseball bats smashed display cases in broad daylight at the Cognacq-Jay Museum in Paris targeting a popular exhibition, Pocket Luxury, which featured small precious objects from the 18th century. Seven valuable tobacco boxes were stolen, some of which had been on loan from the Louvre and the UK‚Äôs royal collection.

The next day, jewellery valued at several million euros was stolen in an armed robbery at around 4pm at the Hi√©ron Museum in Sa√¥ne-et-Loire in central France.

The most notorious museum heist of recent times occurred at the Mus√©e d‚ÄôArt Moderne in Paris in May 2010. Vjeran Tomic, nicknamed Spider-Man, made off with masterpieces by Henri Matisse, Pablo Picasso, Georges Braque, Fernand L√©ger and Amedeo Modigliani valued at more than ‚Ç¨100m.

The case revealed extraordinary security lapses at the museum, including that motion-detection alarms had been out of order for two months, and three guards failed to spot Tomic, who in 2017 was sentenced to eight years in prison.

Agence France-Presse contributed to this report.

title: Man bailed after arrest over ‚Äòracially aggravated‚Äô rape of Sikh woman in West Midlands
description: Police call on public for information as campaigners demand government address increased threat and ‚Äòanti-Sikh hate‚Äô
content:
Police investigating the rape of a British-born Sikh woman in a racially aggravated attack in the West Midlands have made a fresh appeal for public help as they bailed an arrested man.

The woman, in her 20s, reported being attacked by two white men while she was on her way to work in Oldbury on the morning of Tuesday 9 September.

The perpetrators allegedly told her: ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt belong in this country, get out,‚Äù as they attacked her between 8am and 8.30am, according to the Sikh Federation (UK).

A man in his 30s, who was arrested on Sunday on suspicion of rape, has been released on bail pending further inquiries, West Midlands police said on Wednesday. Officers are continuing to appeal for information about the incident which police have described as ‚Äúracially aggravated‚Äù.

The victim is being supported by officers, the force said, as they trawl hundreds of hours of CCTV and carried out ‚Äúextensive‚Äù forensic inquiries. Detectives are urging anyone who saw two white men in the area to come forward. The first man is reported to have had a shaved head, a heavy build and was wearing gloves and a dark coloured sweatshirt, while the second was wearing a grey top with a silver zip.

Chief Superintendent Kim Madill, police commander at Sandwell, said: ‚ÄúWe are working closely with key partners and we absolutely understand the concern of local people.

‚ÄúWe need the public‚Äôs help to bring us information on who has carried out this horrendous attack. I can reassure you that we are doing everything possible to bring those responsible to justice on this young woman‚Äôs behalf.‚Äù

A letter in the joint name of more than 450 UK Gurdwaras and Sikh organisations is being sent to Keir Starmer expressing disappointment at the lack of progress with the case.

The campaigners say there is an increased threat and, citing a number of recent high-profile racist attacks, call on Starmer ‚Äúto encourage the new home secretary and new communities secretary to address anti-Sikh hate‚Äù.

Hundreds of people attended a vigil on Tuesday evening to support the woman. Salman Mirza, one of the organisers, told the Stourbridge News: ‚ÄúWe feel there‚Äôs been a rise in racism and we want unity because we believe this is a good area. We‚Äôve seen the hotel protests and there‚Äôs a lot of division at the moment and we want solidarity.

‚ÄúPeople are outraged and frightened at what‚Äôs happened to this woman ‚Äì we wanted to get together and get women to speak. There‚Äôs a connection between the far right and misogyny.‚Äù

The woman has released a statement thanking the community for its ‚Äúlove and support‚Äù. She said: ‚ÄúI would never wish this on anyone. All I was doing was going about my day on my way to work, and what has happened has deeply affected us.

‚ÄúThrough it all, my family has been my rock and my community has stood strong beside me.‚Äù

title: Nationwide chair first major British lender boss to publicly engage with Reform UK
description: Building society defends Kevin Parry after he attends party‚Äôs breakfast event, sitting next to Richard Tice
content:
Nationwide building society has defended its chair, Kevin Parry, after he became the first boss of a major British lender to publicly engage with Nigel Farage‚Äôs Reform UK party.

It emerged on Wednesday that Parry, who has been chair of the member-owned building society since 2016, attended a breakfast event earlier this week meant to help companies understand Reform‚Äôs approach to business.

The breakfast event was hosted by Sanctuary Counsel, a consultancy focused on ‚Äúbuilding, enhancing and protecting‚Äù the reputation of clients, with Parry seated next to Reform‚Äôs deputy leader, Richard Tice.

It makes Parry the first senior boss from a UK bank or lender to be publicly seen with the party, which has outlined controversial policies including the mass deportation of asylum seekers, ripping up green energy contracts and stripping the City watchdog of its power to regulate the banking industry.

The building society, which is owned by its 17 million members, defended Parry‚Äôs attendance ‚Äì which was first reported by the Financial Times ‚Äì saying it was part of ‚Äúroutine‚Äù engagement with parties across the political spectrum.

A Nationwide spokesperson said: ‚ÄúAs part of his role, our chairman meets with representatives from across the political spectrum. These engagements are routine and reflect our commitment to constructive dialogue on issues that matter to our members and the wider sector.‚Äù

Business leaders have been closely watching Reform after its sweeping local election victories this year and as opinion polls suggest it could win hundreds of seats at a general election. But while Reform said it had welcomed hundreds of businesses to its annal conference in Birmingham earlier this month, most groups sent junior staff, with bosses still concerned about being associated with the rightwing party.

All of the UK‚Äôs ‚Äúbig five‚Äù trade bodies ‚Äì including the CBI, British Chambers of Commerce and Federation of Small Businesses ‚Äì dispatched public affairs executives to the conference.

Heathrow sponsored an airport-style lounge for business delegates and First Group provided double-decker buses for meetings. JCB, the digger-maker owned by Lord Bamford, the billionaire former Conservative donor who is now backing Reform, was also an exhibitor, and other corporate attenders included Airbnb and Japan Tobacco International.

TikTok sponsored a drinks reception where Reform councillors and the party‚Äôs newest MP, Sarah Pochin, rubbed shoulders with corporate lobbyists over complimentary canap√©s, pints and cocktails.

However, companies are also treating the party with caution. One corporate affairs boss, who stayed away from the Reform conference, told the Guardian at the time: ‚ÄúEveryone feels awkward, no one wants to be called out as being there.‚Äù

title: The life and death of Charlie Kirk: inside the 19 September Guardian Weekly
description:
America reacts to the death of a Maga super influencer. Plus: the Boris files

‚Ä¢ Get the Guardian Weekly magazine delivered to your home address
content:
The killing of Charlie Kirk last week sent shock waves through America among both supporters and opponents of his views. Yet until last week, the young rightwing activist was relatively unheard of ‚Äì by older generations anyway ‚Äì outside the US.

As the ripples and implications of his death continue to spread across the US and beyond, our big story takes a step back. Washington bureau chief David Smith explains how the young activist rose to prominence and gained a place within Donald Trump‚Äôs inner circle, his provocative brand of populism and charisma playing an outsize role in the Republicans‚Äô 2024 election victory. As Steve Bannon, the prominent rightwing commentator, told the Guardian, Kirk‚Äôs popularity with young voters ‚Äúchanged the ground game‚Äù for Trump and the Maga movement.

Kirk‚Äôs shooting also returned the focus to the vexed issue of gun control in the US. Ed Pilkington examines whether a country where weapons violence has become normalised is prepared to ask searching questions of itself. And commentator Jonathan Freedland gives a pessimistic prognosis that a ‚Äúcountry born in violence‚Äù shows even less inclination under Trump than it may have done in previous administrations to heal the division that is pulling American society apart.

title: Trump DoJ seeks to kill Vermont law that makes big oil pay for climate harm
description: Justice department asks judge to shut down ‚Äòsuperfund‚Äô law that requires major polluters to pay for carbon emissions
content:
Donald Trump‚Äôs justice department has asked a judge to shut down a Vermont law which holds major polluters financially responsible for climate damages.

In a brief filed on Monday in a federal court in Burlington, the administration said the policy was ‚Äúunlawful on its face‚Äù and pushed the court to ‚Äúend Vermont‚Äôs lawless experiment‚Äù.

‚ÄúThe Court should deny the motions to dismiss, grant the United States‚Äô motion for summary judgment, declare the Superfund Act unconstitutional and unenforceable, and permanently enjoin Defendants from taking any actions to implement or enforce it,‚Äù Riley Walters, counsel to an acting assistant attorney general, wrote in the motion.

Passed in 2024, the Vermont policy ‚Äì known as the Climate Superfund Act ‚Äì requires major polluters to pay for their carbon emissions, which have warmed the planet and increased the intensity and frequency of extreme weather events, such as the floods which wreaked $1bn in damage on the state last year. New York passed a similar measure in December.

‚ÄúThis law is about holding big oil accountable for a portion of the damage it has already brought to Vermont‚Äôs farms, businesses, homeowners and communities,‚Äù said Paul Burns, executive director of the Vermont Public Interest Research Group, one of the organizations that helped to pass Vermont‚Äôs Climate Superfund law. ‚ÄúVermont is well within its rights to protect its people in this way.‚Äù

The filing comes four months after the Department of Justice and Environmental Protection Agency sued Vermont and New York over the laws. In August, the state and two non-profits who were granted intervenor status, the Conservation Law Foundation and the Northeast Organic Farming Association of Vermont, asked the judge to dismiss the lawsuit.

Kate Sinding Daly, senior vice-president for law and policy at the Conservation Law Foundation, said her organization would ‚Äúcontinue to defend the state‚Äôs climate superfund law meant to protect the wallets of Vermont‚Äôs families and businesses.

‚ÄúLet‚Äôs be clear: this law is not a sweeping effort to regulate global greenhouse gas emissions, punish fossil fuel companies, or set federal policy on climate change,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThis is Vermont using its legal right to raise revenue and protect the health, safety, and wellbeing of its residents from the ruinous, inescapable consequences of climate change.‚Äù

The motion is the latest attempt by the Trump administration to quash climate accountability efforts and environmental regulations. In an April executive order, Trump instructed the justice department to ‚Äústop the enforcement‚Äù of climate superfund policies.

Related: Trump effort to ditch greenhouse gas finding ignores ‚Äòclearcut‚Äô science, expert says

In July, the administration proposed undoing the 2009 ‚Äúendangerment finding‚Äù, which says planet-warming emissions endanger public health and should therefore be regulated under the Clean Air Act ‚Äì the most audacious of more than 150 environmental rollbacks launched since Trump retook office in January.

Jamie Henn, director of the anti-fossil fuel non-profit Fossil Free Media, which backs the superfund laws, said Trump‚Äôs assault would not deter efforts to bring about financial accountability for global warming. Legislators in at least a dozen states are looking to introduce or reintroduce climate superfund bills in 2026, he said.

‚ÄúThe latest polling shows that 74% of voters, including a majority of Republicans, support making oil and gas companies pay their fair share for climate damages,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúNo wonder the Trump administration and their big oil donors see climate superfund laws as such a threat: these are popular, commonsense policies that will help cities, states and families offset the costs of extreme weather and other climate impacts.‚Äù

title: England beat Ireland by four wickets first men‚Äôs T20 international ‚Äì as it happened
description: The remarkable Phil Salt fell just short of another century as England chased 197 down with 14 balls remaining
content:
5.46pm BST

That‚Äôs your lot. I‚Äôll leave you with Taha Hashim‚Äôs report. Bye!

Related: Salt thrashes England past Ireland in first T20 as Bethell‚Äôs big day goes to plan

5.06pm BST

The player of the match is Phil Salt

I enjoyed that. It was a pretty good wicket and it‚Äôs a good ground to bat on when you get going. Yeah. good fun.

[On his partnership with Jos Buttler] That‚Äôs the way we play I suppose. We both try to take it on really early, and when it works it looks good.

[On missing out on a century] Ah, potentially. But I don‚Äôt want to start thinking like that ‚Äì we won the first game of the series and I‚Äôm happy with that.

5.04pm BST

Jacob Bethell's verdict

It feels pretty special [to captain England], and to win the first one is always nice. Great feeling and I can‚Äôt want to get going again on Friday.

Coming off the field we probably thought Ireland had got a few too many, but the conditions here were a bit of an unknown. Now, going into Friday and Sunday. we know how to defend and take wickets at this place.

[On Salt and Buttler] I think their average opening partnership is about 55 with a ridiculous strike rate, so for me personally batting after them is pretty nice! We‚Äôve also got a lot of depth which means everyone can go really hard.

I said to a couple of the guys, there‚Äôs aren‚Äôt many sports where you get the two extremes: ou get the proper big stadiums and then you get to bring it back home almost to a ground like this. It‚Äôs a lovely ground and I‚Äôve heard Friday and Sunday are sold out so hopefully the atmosphere will be even better.

4.58pm BST

Paul Stirling‚Äôs reaction

There were multiple positives to take and hopefully across the three games we can improve. We were pretty happy with 196 ‚Äì but we also knew we had to get everything right in the field, and we didn‚Äôt quite manage that.

We kept trying to take wickets. That‚Äôs all you can do in cricket these days ‚Äì there‚Äôs no point being ultra-defensive.

We‚Äôve got a big winter ahead of us and this is the start of that.

4.48pm BST

The matchwinner ‚Äì stop me if you think etc ‚Äì was Phil Salt, who pannelled89 from 46 balls to take England to the brink of victory. His last two T20 innings have yielded 230 runs for one dismissal from 106 balls, with 25 fours, 12 sixes and umpteen statgasms.

4.47pm BST

England win by four wickets with 14 balls remaining!

17th over: England 197-6 (Jacks 1, Overton 4) Overton hustles a full toss from McCarthy down the ground for four to complete a comfortable win for England in Jacob Bethell‚Äôs first game as captain.

Updated at 4.54pm BST

4.43pm BST

17th over: England 191-6 (Jacks 0, Overton 0) That was the last ball of the over. The margin of victory/defeat will flatter Ireland a touch; equally, they‚Äôve done well to take it this deep because at one stage they were disappearing for a boundary a ball.

4.42pm BST

WICKET! England 191-6 (Banton c Campher b Humphreys 11)

WHATEVER HAPPENED TO RED-INK CULTURE? Tom Banton reverses Humphreys for a couple of boundaries before blasting straight to mid-on. He could have milked a single and got a nice not out.

Updated at 4.42pm BST

4.39pm BST

16th over: England 181-5 (Salt 89, Curran 15) Hume‚Äôs figures now look a bit healthier: 2-0-36-2. Still bonkers, but nowhere near as grisly as they were after two balls of the over.

4.38pm BST

WICKET! England 181-5 (Salt c Adair b Hume 89)

No century for Phil Salt! It‚Äôs almost a shock to type that given how comfortable he looked. But he chased a very wide, very full ball from Hume and sliced it straight to Adair at deep backward point. Salt whacks his bat angrily on the way off; his standards are so high these days that 89 isn‚Äôt good enough.

Updated at 4.58pm BST

4.36pm BST

WICKET! England 180-4 (Curran c Dockrell b Hume 27)

Poor Graham Hume is having a day to forget. His first over was Buttlered for 22; now Sam Curran has hit him for successive sixes at the start of the second. They‚Äôre two superb shots, pulled over square leg and lasered over extra cover, and as I type Hume is nursing figures of 1.2-0-35-0. It‚Äôs nothing personal, just Baziness.

Hume eventually catches a break when Curran, aiming for his third straight six, picks out Dockrell on the midwicket boundary.

Updated at 4.39pm BST

4.31pm BST

15th over: England 167-3 (Salt 89, Curran 15) Curran deposits Humphreys over long-on for his first six, which means all 10 players who have had a bat today have hit at least one six. But only one has a chance of making a century; Salt is now 11 away with 30 runs needed for victory.

4.26pm BST

14th over: England 154-3 (Salt 84, Curran 6) Salt biffs McCarthy to deep extra cover and races back for the second. The umpire checks for the run-out but it‚Äôs a precautionary measure; Salt was comfortably home.

McCarthy is about to bowl to Salt when the wind blows one of the bails off; he jokingly raises the finger to give Salt out.

Salt smiles and whacks the next ball for four. He‚Äôs 15 away from a century.

4.20pm BST

13th over: England 147-3 (Salt 78, Curran 6) Glenn Maxwell and Rohit Sharma have a record five T20I centirues from 114 and 151 innings respectively. This is Salt‚Äôs 43rd T20I innings, and he didn‚Äôt score his first hundred until the 18th. What he‚Äôs doing is barely legal.

It‚Äôd be funny if, after all this premature statgasming, England went on to lose the game. They need 50 from 42 balls.

4.16pm BST

12th over: England 141-3 (Salt 76, Curran 2) Salt is denied another boundary, this time off Young, by a spectacular diving stop from Campher at cow corner. The upshot is one of the few boundaryless overs of the day.

‚ÄúAfternoon Rob,‚Äù writes Kimberley Thonger. ‚ÄúCan you pull any strings and please get a message sent out from the England dressing room for them to slow the scoring rate a bit? My daughter-in-law is in labour and I need to be distracted from that as long as possible. It‚Äôs not much to ask is it? They‚Äôll have polished this total off before she‚Äôs even started pushing properly if something isn‚Äôt said.‚Äù

Congratulations! I‚Äôll try to telepathise this to Phil Salt.

4.12pm BST

11th over: England 137-3 (Salt 73, Curran 1) Salt deposits a long hop into the crowd to move to 73 from 31 balls. The fella needs help, he can‚Äôt stop committing acts of violence against a cricket ball.

Updated at 4.28pm BST

4.10pm BST

WICKET! England 130-3 (Rehan b Delany 8)

The legspinner Gareth Delany, playing his 100th white-ball international for Ireland, comes tantalisingly close to taking a wicket with his first ball.

Rehan sliced him towards short third, where Hume swooped forward to grab the ball very close to the ground. Hume shook his head, unconvinced it was a clean catch. The umpires went upstairs anyway; the replays were inconclusive and Rehan was given not out.

Not that it made much difference, even in the short term. Two balls later Rehan charged Delany, missed a sinew-straining smear and was bowled by a ball that kept a bit low. A nice moment for Delany on his landmark day.

4.05pm BST

10th over: England 130-2 (Salt 67, Rehan 8) Rehan Ahmed pulls Curtis Campher‚Äôs second ball flat and hard for six. A single turns the strike over to Salt, who blisters another short ball to cow corner for four. He needs 33 for another century. Even if he doesn‚Äôt achieve it, his T20 record is just silly.

4.00pm BST

9th over: England 117-2 (Salt 61, Rehan 1) Rehan Ahmed is the new batter. This is the first time he‚Äôs batted higher than No8 for England in white-ball cricket, though he looks increasingly comfortable up the order for Leicestershire and Trent Rockets.

Updated at 4.01pm BST

3.59pm BST

WICKET! England 116-2 (Bethell c Adair b Tector 24)

Six and out for Jacob Bethell. He hit 14 from three balls, culminating in a huge slog-swept six that necessitated a ball replacement, then sliced Tector straight to extra cover.

So much for rotating the strike! But Bethell‚Äôs cameo of 24 from 16 balls has moved England closer to a crushing victory.

Updated at 4.18pm BST

3.53pm BST

8th over: England 102-1 (Salt 61, Bethell 10) Bethell is giving the strike to Salt at every opportunity, an obvious tactic but one that not all 21-year-old captains would care for on their big day.

Salt carts Young to cow corner for four, just wide of the diving Campher near the boundary, then smears another past the bowler to bring up the hundred in 7.3 overs. Salt has a chance of another century himself; it would be his fifth, equalling the record of Glenn Maxwell and Rohit Sharma.

England need 95 from 72 balls. Don‚Äôt we all.

Updated at 3.54pm BST

3.48pm BST

7th over: England 91-1 (Salt 52, Bethell 8) That cock-up aside it‚Äôs a good first over from Tector, who is only an occasional offspinner. No boundaries, seven from it.

3.47pm BST

Salt caught off a no-ball

Salt slugs a high full toss from the offspinner Harry Tector to deep midwicket ‚Äì but it‚Äôs a front-foot no-ball! Oh, Harry.

3.45pm BST

Salt races to 20-ball fifty

6th over: England 84-1 (Salt 50, Bethell 5) Salt moves to a 20-ball fifty with a cut for four off McCarthy. Just another day at the T20 office for him. If he‚Äôs still in after 10 overs he‚Äôll be eyeing his fifth T20I century.

Salt might be England‚Äôs Heinrich Klaasen ‚Äì not in style or role, but the man whose numbers blow the mind of neutrals around the world. At the time of typing, he has a T20I average of 38 and a strike rate of 171. What even is that?

‚ÄúIt must be so dispiriting to post a solid total and then in the space of 20 balls be staring down the barrel of a now near run-a-ball chase,‚Äù says Eddy Nason. ‚ÄúThese two opening is a cheat code.‚Äù

England may have to change their plans for the World Cup, which involved Ben Duckett opening, possibly Jamie Smith too. I guess Buttler will drop down to No3 but it must be tempting to keep cheating.

Updated at 3.48pm BST

3.40pm BST

5th over: England 74-1 (Salt 45, Bethell 0) In statistical terms Salt and Buttler are the most devastating partnership in T20I history: 1145 runs at an average of 52 and a run-rate of 10.71.

Both the average and the run-rate are the highest among pairs who have added at least 1000 runs.

3.37pm BST

WICKET! England 74-1 (Buttler c Campher b Buttler 28)

Usually on the OBO we try to provide at least a basic description of every boundary. You can sing for that today! Salt smashes Humphreys for four and six ‚Äì but now Buttler has gone, caught at mid-on after being done in the flight by Humphreys. Nicely bowled.

Buttler made 28 from 10 balls, and now it‚Äôs time for England‚Äôs new captain to have a bat.

Updated at 3.56pm BST

3.33pm BST

4th over: England 63-0 (Salt 34, Buttler 28) Craig Young is the latest bowler to trry his luck. Salt lashes his first two balls for four, because in 2025 this is normal behaviour, apparently, but Young does well to stall England for the rest of the over.

Now, who would like a statgasm? Since the start of the T20 against South Africa on Friday, Salt and Buttler have added 189 in 11.5 overs.

3.29pm BST

Buttler smashes 24 off the third over

3rd over: England 52-0 (Salt 24, Buttler 27) Jos Buttler has been in awesome form of late, the cricketing embodiment of his famous mantra, and he has just belted Graham Hume‚Äôs first over for 24.

Where to start? With the almost absent-minded swipe over mid-on for four, I guess. That was followed by an elegantly violent drive over long-off for six and a cuff through the coivers. Hume beat him with a slower ball; Buttler waved the next over mid-off before ending the over with a devastating straight hit for four. Sheesh.

Oh, that brought up the fifty partnership inside three overs.

3.23pm BST

2nd over: England 30-0 (Salt 24, Buttler 5) Salt picks a slower ball from Barry McCarthy and desecrates it down the ground for six. He follows that with a brusque slap through extra cover and a brusque smear over midwicket for six more. The ball hit the rope on the half-volley.

Updated at 3.31pm BST

3.17pm BST

1st over: England 11-0 (Salt 7, Buttler 4) Phil Salt makes a desperately slow start, taking THREE deliveries to hit his first boundary. Jos Buttler then cuts the last ball of the over, his first, sweetly for four more.

3.13pm BST

Phil Salt and Jos Buttler, fresh from pulverising South Africa, walk out to begin the England runchase. Ireland will open up with the left-arm spinner Matthew Humphreys.

2.54pm BST

England need 197 to win

20th over: Ireland 196-3 (Tector 61, Dockrell 6) George Dockrell strolls to the middle, picks Jamie Overton up over square leg for six and walks off. Nice work if you can get it, and do it.

Adil Rashid is interviewed on his way off. He says Ireland ‚Äúplayed exceptionally well‚Äù on a slowish pitch but that England are confident of chasing 197.

Updated at 2.55pm BST

2.53pm BST

WICKET! Ireland 190-3 (Tucker c Buttler b Overton 55)

Tucker brings up a hard-hitting fifty by launching Overton for six over long off. He falls next ball, top-edging a sharp bumper through to Buttler. Lovely innings from Tucker: 55 from 36 balls with four sixes.

Ireland have one delivery remaining.

Updated at 3.05pm BST

2.49pm BST

19th over: Ireland 181-2 (Tector 59, Tucker 48) Tucker clumps Curran for a straight six, the start of a damaging over for England. Tector picks up successive boundaries in the other V, the one behind the batsmen, and Curran ends with 4-0-43-0. Ireland still have an outside chance of reaching 200.

2.45pm BST

Fifty for Tector

18th over: Ireland 163-2 (Tector 50, Tucker 40) Harry Tector is such a good player. He plonks Adil Rashid emphatically over midwicket for six, his second and Ireland‚Äôs ninth, then pushes two down the ground to reach a stylish fifty from 31 balls.

Rashid finishes with figures of 4-0-36-1.

2.42pm BST

17th over: Ireland 151-2 (Tector 40, Tucker 38) After a strong start to his third over, Curran is pulled witheringly through midwicket for four by Tector. England won‚Äôt be worried about the upcoming runchase ‚Äì good pitch, small ground ‚Äì but it hasn‚Äôt been their best bowling performance.

Nothing much to report in terms of Bethell‚Äôs captaincy, not that I‚Äôve seen from the TV anyway.

Updated at 2.45pm BST

2.40pm BST

Play is finally under way at the Oval, where Surrey and Nottinghamshire are involved in a (probable) title decider. Tanya Aldred is there for us.

Related: Surrey v Nottinghamshire, Sussex v Yorkshire, and more: county cricket, day three ‚Äì live

2.38pm BST

16th over: Ireland 142-2 (Tector 34, Tucker 36) Dawson ends a reasonable spell, no more of less, with figures of 4-0-39-1.

2.33pm BST

15th over: Ireland 133-2 (Tector 28, Tucker 34) Luke Wood starts his second spell with a shortish delivery that is spanked through midwicket for four by Tucker. That‚Äôs an imperious shot, matched by a drive over long off for six later in the over.

Wood continues a poor over with a wide half-volley that Tector slices over the top for four.

2.30pm BST

Fifty partnership between Tector and Tucker

14th over: Ireland 118-2 (Tector 24, Tucker 23) Tector pulls Overton for a single to bring up an accomplished fifty partnership from 31 balls. Tucker charges and misses a low full toss that comes this close to violating the off stump. Why have I got Todd Carty on the brain all of a sudden?

Excellent over from Overton, three from it.

2.26pm BST

Review: Tucker overturns LBW decision

13th over: Ireland 115-2 (Tector 23, Tucker 21) Rashid lets slip a disgusting full toss that is carted over midwicket for six by Tucker. It looked above waist height but a no-ball wasn‚Äôt called.

Three balls later Tector is given out LBW on the back foot after playing round a beautiful legbreak. Was it missing off stump? Tector thinks so and has reviewed; I suspect it‚Äôs umpire‚Äôs call.

I suspect wrong. It would have missed off stump by a whisker so Tucker continues. Gorgeous bowling from Rashid, though, who with one filthy exception was at his mischievous, probing best throughout that over.

Updated at 3.06pm BST

2.21pm BST

12th over: Ireland 103-2 (Tector 23, Tucker 14) Tector and Tucker are class players who will punish England if they don‚Äôt sharpen up. Dawson is too straight and swept round the corner for four by Tucker, a boundary that brings up the hundred inside the 12th over.

Tucker ends the over with an even better stroke, lofted down the ground for four more. Beautiful batting.

2.17pm BST

11th over: Ireland 96-2 (Tector 17, Tucker 8) Sam Curran bowls a leg-side wide that spins past Buttler to the boundary, a moment that should have been soundtracked by the theme from Curb.

Not a great over from Curran, this. A poor ball on leg stump is flicked past short fine leg for four by Tucker.

2.14pm BST

10th over: Ireland 84-2 (Tector 15, Tucker 4) Rehan Ahmed, playing his first T2o international since the tour of the Caribbean last November, makes a decent start with the ball. His first delivery was cut for four but he kept things relatively tight thereafter.

2.10pm BST

9th over: Ireland 75-2 (Tector 9, Tucker 1) Ireland aren‚Äôt going to die wondering. Tector belts the sixth six of the innings, and his first, with a slog-sweep off Rashid.

2.08pm BST

WICKET! Ireland 67-2 (Stirling c Jacks b Rashid 34)

Paul Stirling was on the charge. He has just holed out to long on, done in the flight by Adil Rashid, and is on his way for 34 from 22 balls. A good cameo that has given the Ireland innings a bit of momentum.

Updated at 3.11pm BST

2.05pm BST

8th over: Ireland 66-1 (Stirling 34, Tector 1) Paul Stirling is on the charge. He backs away to cream a short ball from Dawson over long off for his fourth six. Stirling has 34 from 21 balls, including 29 off his last 13.

Updated at 3.09pm BST

2.02pm BST

WICKET! Ireland 57-1 (Adair c Salt b Dawson 26)

Liam Dawson makes the breakthrough. Ross Adair mistimed a slog sweep towards deep midwicket, where Phil Salt took a comfortable catch.

2.00pm BST

7th over: Ireland 57-0 (Stirling 26, Adair 26) Adil Rashid starts with a fullbunger to Stirling, who mauls it down the ground for six more. After that rare loosener, Rashid gets into his work and concedes only a couple of runs from the last five balls.

1.57pm BST

6th over: Ireland 49-0 (Stirling 19, Adair 25) That blow seems to have sharpened Adair‚Äôs senses. He hits 10 off Overton‚Äôs last two balls, including a spectacular drive over extra-cover for six, to complete an increasingly good Powerplay for Ireland.

1.55pm BST

5.4 overs: Ireland 39-0 (Stirling 19, Adair 15) Adair charges Overton, misses a yahoo and is hit on the grille. There‚Äôs a short break in play while the physio runs on to do the necessary.

Updated at 2.19pm BST

1.51pm BST

5th over: Ireland 32-0 (Stirling 18, Adair 11) Sam Curran replaces Luke Wood ‚Äì Monsieur, with these left-armers you‚Äôre really spoiling us ‚Äì and tries a slower ball to Stirling. Wrong! Stirling monsters it over midwicket for his second six.

That aside there‚Äôs only one run from five balls, a continuation of Ireland‚Äôs inability to rotate strike early on.

1.46pm BST

4th over: Ireland 25-0 (Stirling 12, Adair 10) Liam Dawson comes into the attack. Ireland‚Äôs openers are struggling to time the ball ‚Äì but Stirling gets enough on a lofted shot to hit Dawson for six over wide mid-off. It‚Äôs a relatively short boundary, so it went the distance even though he didn‚Äôt middle it.

Updated at 1.46pm BST

1.42pm BST

3rd over: Ireland 16-0 (Stirling 5, Adair 9) Adair slugs Wood‚Äôs change-up, the short ball, over midwicket for two; he didn‚Äôt time it properly. Those are the only runs off the bat in a good over from Wood.

1.39pm BST

2nd over: Ireland 13-0 (Stirling 5, Adair 7) Jamie Overton cuts Ross Adair in half with a sharp back-of-a-length delivery. Adair plays his sod-this-for-a-lark card, charging the next ball and slicing it over the infield for two. Not the most convincing shot, though, and he looks a bit uneasy with Overton‚Äôs pace.

The moment I type that he plays his most convincing shot by far, a sweet drive through extra cover for four.

1.34pm BST

1st over: Ireland 7-0 (Stirling 5, Adair 1) Luke Wood takes a couple of deliveries to get going. His first ball is a wide; his first legal delivery is larruped to the cover boundary by Stirling.

The rest of the over is better. An inswinging yorker is well defended by Stirling, who then inside edges past the stumps.

1.32pm BST

Luke Wood, Lancashire‚Äôs left-arm swing bowler, will open up to Paul Stirling and Ross Adair.

1.29pm BST

‚ÄúIreland in mid-September?‚Äù begins Robert Wilson, although he did right ‚ÄòDear Rob‚Äô before that and on reflection it was unfair of me to exclude that as you may unjustly deem him a man of few manners. ‚ÄúIconoclastic meteorological choice, that one. From the last week of September to the third week in May, the Irish sky is black as a bruise, fourteen inches above your eyebrows and it blames you - for everything. It‚Äôs a sky for crouching under and thinking of mortality‚Äôs sweet release. Forget spin or swing, the ball is more likely to commit suicide than anything else.

‚ÄúYes, I admit the sun is splitting the trees here in Paris, but I paid my bloody dues with that sky. I get to put the boot in.

‚ÄúPS Fluffing a bit of ground fielding in Ireland comes with finger pain that is simply unavailable anywhere else (the Scottish may demur but they‚Äôre notorious liars about such things).‚Äù

1.24pm BST

The players line up for the anthems. The weather in Malahide was vile overnight, it says here, but it‚Äôs dry now and there‚Äôs even a suggestion of sunshine.

1.15pm BST

Ireland‚Äôs winter starts here

The ongoing struggles and frustrations of Irish cricket are covered in this excellent piece from Taha.

A lack of cricket at home is an ongoing problem. Last year Cricket Ireland called off a tour by Australia, and Afghanistan‚Äôs visit this summer was also cancelled, the governing body citing ‚Äúfinancial reasons‚Äù. With no permanent stadium infrastructure, the costs of transforming club grounds into international venues has been a major stumbling block.

‚ÄúWe effectively have to build everything,‚Äù says Warren Deutrom, who stepped away as CI‚Äôs chief executive last month after 19 years in the job. Up go the temporary stands for England‚Äôs visit.

Yet these cancellations come as CI‚Äôs annual income jumped from ‚Ç¨10.2m (¬£8.8m) to ‚Ç¨16.4m (¬£14.2m) in 2024 thanks to increased funding from the International Cricket Council. Deutrom‚Äôs retort is that the governing body has had to direct more attention to other areas of the sport.

Related: Ireland‚Äôs near-empty cricket summer in stark contrast to England‚Äôs slate

1.14pm BST

Taha Hashim‚Äôs series preview

Harry Tector and Paul Stirling ‚Äúare the two main threats with the bat‚Äù for Ireland, said [Jacob] Bethell. The hosts enter underprepared having not played since June ‚Äì a completely different story to England ‚Äì and will be without the whippy left-arm pace of Josh Little, on the mend from a rib injury. Yet the only completed T20 meeting between these two sides brought an Irish victory in Melbourne at the World Cup three years ago, a reminder that it may not be all smooth for Bethell over the coming days.

Related: England‚Äôs youngest-ever captain Bethell happy to ‚Äògo in at deep end‚Äô against Ireland

1.11pm BST

The teams

Ireland are without some key players, most notably Josh Little and Mark Adair, but can still put out a strong side. Gareth Delany is winning his 100th international cap.

Ireland Stirling (c), R Adair, H Tector, Tucker (wk), Delany, Dockrell, Campher, McCarthy, Hume, Humphreys, Young.

England Salt, Buttler (wk), Bethell (c), Rehan, Banton, S Curran, Jacks, J Overton, Dawson, Rashid, L Wood.

Updated at 1.28pm BST

1.02pm BST

England win the toss and bowl

They‚Äôve only gone and picked Rehan Ahmed ‚Äì and he‚Äôs carded to come in at No4! Rehan and Jamie Overton replace Harry Brook and Jofra Archer, the only changes to the side that marmalised South Africa at Old Trafford last Friday.

Paul Stirling says Ireland would also have bowled first.

Updated at 1.18pm BST

12.55pm BST

If I may borrow a phrase from Michael Holding, pace is pace. And this is a cracking piece from Jim Wallace on what it‚Äôs like when bowling 90mph+ feels like the easiest thing in the world.

Related: The Spin | Speed thrills: from Donald to Archer, why pace is a spectacle like no other

12.50pm BST

Preamble

It‚Äôs 23 October 2003 ‚Äì no, really, it is! ‚Äì and England‚Äôs inaugural Test match against Bangladesh is becoming a bit of struggle. After dominating the first two days, they slip from 137 for 0 to 295 all out, with Marcus Trescothick thwacking 111 and Graham Thorpe* batting almost four hours for a skilful 64. ‚ÄúA pretty sorry first-innings effort‚Äù is the verdict of Dan Rookwood on the Guardian OBO.

Bangladesh finished the day on 12 for 1 in their second innings, a deficit of 80, and England hit the hay with a slippery fourth-innings chase on their mind. (Spoiler alert: England eventually cantered to a target of 164 inside 40 overs to win by seven wickets.)

On the same day, a Bajan couple welcomed their first child into the world. Graham and Giselle Bethell christened him Jacob Graham, and they will be among the proudest people on earth today when he captains England in the first T20 international against Malahide.

Feeling old? Don‚Äôt worry you are. When Bethell was born, Sugababes were top of the hit parade with Hole in the Head, England were a month away from winning the men‚Äôs rugby World Cup, Twenty20 cricket was barely four months old and nobody was suffering death by a thousand notifications.

At 21 years 329 days, Bethell will demolish the record for England‚Äôs youngest-ever captain, set unknowingly by Montague Bowden (23y 144d) in 1888-89. Scheduling a match in Malahide in mid-September comes with certain meteorological risks, but the weather is fine and there‚Äôs no danger of a washout. Ireland‚Äôs aim is turn Bethell‚Äôs big day into a damp squib.

The match starts at 1.30pm

* If you love Thorpey as much as the rest of us, this interview with the great Don McRae before that Bangladesh series is a fascinating and poignant read. I don‚Äôt know whether it needs a trigger warning or not but, if it counts for anything, I had a lump in my throat when I read it

Updated at 12.52pm BST

title: Jimmy Kimmel: Republicans ‚Äòworking very hard to capitalize‚Äô on Charlie Kirk‚Äôs killing
description: Late-night hosts discuss Maga‚Äôs baseless claims about ‚Äòviolence‚Äô from the ‚Äòfar left‚Äô and Trump‚Äôs new $15bn lawsuit against the New York Times
content:
Late-show hosts recap Donald Trump‚Äôs chilly reception in the UK, his corrupt business deals with the UAE and Maga‚Äôs fearmongering around the ‚Äúradical left‚Äù.

Jimmy Kimmel

On Monday night, Trump became the first US president to sue the New York Times, for defamation to the tune of $15bn. ‚ÄúWhere does he even come up with this?‚Äù wondered Jimmy Kimmel on Tuesday evening. ‚ÄúThese are like numbers my children make up when they‚Äôre talking about money.‚Äù

‚ÄúI thought he said the New York Times was failing,‚Äù he added. ‚ÄúHe thinks they have $15bn? How much would he sue for if he thought they were doing well?‚Äù

‚ÄúHe won‚Äôt win this. The New York Times won‚Äôt settle,‚Äù Kimmel noted. ‚ÄúBesides how ridiculous it is, this might be one of the funniest legal documents I‚Äôve ever seen. It‚Äôs quite a tongue bath.‚Äù One page lists Trump‚Äôs ‚Äúhundreds of history-making appearances‚Äù including WrestleMania V, All My Children, Ghosts Can‚Äôt Do It, Two Weeks Notice, the Miss America pageants and ‚Äúmuch more‚Äù.

‚ÄúThis is quite a resume,‚Äù Kimmel deadpanned. ‚ÄúYou know he met Melania on 90 Day Fiance.‚Äù

Related: Seth Meyers: ‚ÄòTrump clearly has no answer to Putin‚Äôs aggression‚Äô

Meanwhile, ‚Äúmany in Maga-land are working very hard to capitalize on the murder of Charlie Kirk‚Äù. On Monday, JD Vance, who once called Trump ‚ÄúAmerica‚Äôs Hitler‚Äù, hosted Kirk‚Äôs podcast from the White House and blamed the left, without evidence. Said Vance: ‚ÄúWhile our side of the aisle certainly has its crazies, it is a statistical fact that most of the lunatics in American politics today are proud members of the far left.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd by ‚Äòstatistical fact‚Äô, he means ‚Äòcomplete bullshit‚Äô,‚Äù Kimmel corrected. In fact, the Department of Justice removed from its website a study finding that violence from far-right groups is the greatest source of domestic terror and extremist violence in the US. ‚ÄúHere‚Äôs a question JD Vance might be able to answer: who wanted to hang the guy who was vice president before you?‚Äù Kimmel said. ‚ÄúWas that the liberal left? Or the toothless army who stormed the Capitol on January 6.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe president and his henchmen are doing their best to fan the flames, so they can I guess attack people on the dangerous left,‚Äù Kimmel added, noting the incongruence with the right‚Äôs former vision of so-called ‚Äúsnowflake‚Äù liberals. ‚ÄúWhich is it?‚Äù he wondered. ‚ÄúAre they a bunch of sissy pickleball players because they‚Äôre too scared to get hit by tennis balls? Or are they a well-organized army of commandos? Because they can‚Äôt be both.‚Äù

Stephen Colbert

On the Late Show, Stephen Colbert celebrated the show‚Äôs first Emmy win for outstanding variety talk series with their trophy on stage. ‚ÄúMan, I‚Äôm telling you, we should‚Äôve gotten cancelled years ago,‚Äù he joked.

‚ÄúThis award belongs to all 200 of the incredibly hardworking people who make this show,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúFirst and foremost, the writers of this show‚Äù as well as the ‚Äústage crew, production staff, talent, segment editors, the band, control room, props, graphics, research, footage, digital, accounting, legal, wardrobe, makeup, security, maintenance, assistants and interns‚Äù.

‚ÄúAnd, of course, the audience department who let in all of you gorgeous people every night,‚Äù he added. ‚ÄúYou are the ones who ultimately make this show possible. So this belongs to you, but I‚Äôm going to keep it.‚Äù

‚ÄúSpeaking of Emmys, Donald Trump doesn‚Äôt have one,‚Äù he continued. ‚ÄúAlso, right now, he‚Äôs out of the country, making his second state visit to the UK. But for a state visit, Trump is going to be keeping it surprisingly low profile.‚Äù The President will stay behind closed doors at Windsor Castle, far from massive planned protests and without delivering a traditional address to potential critics in Parliament. Still, protesters managed to unfurl a giant banner on the castle lawn with an old picture of Trump and his friend Jeffrey Epstein.

‚ÄúWhat are they going to do with it after Trump‚Äôs state visit?‚Äù Colbert wondered. ‚Äú‚ÄòChildren, we have a donation of a very unfortunate parachute for today‚Äôs gym class.‚Äô‚Äù

While he‚Äôs there, Trump will be treated to an opulent banquet at Windsor Castle and a carriage ride through the grounds. ‚ÄúOh, the pageantry!‚Äù Colbert joked. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs just like Cinderella, but good luck slipping the glass slipper on those cankles.‚Äù

Seth Meyers

And on Late Night, Seth Meyers recapped a New York Times investigation into how the Trump family made $2bn in cryptocurrency deals with the UAE, in exchange for giving the Emirati government access to advanced AI chips. ‚ÄúWho am I to say that these two things are connected?‚Äù Meyers joked. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs totally possible that Donald Trump Sr was negotiating the chips deal while Donald Trump Jr was negotiating the crypto deal, and they had no idea until it was time to sign the contract, and then they both showed up at the same restaurant at the same time and said ‚ÄòDon, what are you doing here?‚Äô‚Äù

‚ÄúThis is obviously, ludicrously corrupt,‚Äù he said. When a reporter asked Trump on Tuesday about his business deals, Trump pivoted to ‚Äúwhat has recently become his favorite topic‚Äù: the new White House ballroom, which Trump said ‚Äúwill knock your socks off‚Äù.

‚ÄúStop talking about the fucking ballroom!‚Äù Meyers begged. ‚ÄúNo one gives a shit about the ballroom. Prices are skyrocketing and our freedoms are disappearing all around us, and you‚Äôre going on about a ballroom like a fop from Dangerous Liaisons.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou think the farmers in Iowa who voted for you are sitting down for coffee at their local diners saying, ‚Äòwell, the tariffs are killing my business, but at least the White House will finally have a place to hold fancy proms?‚Äô‚Äù

Meyers also mocked Trump for threatening the Australian reporter who asked about the UAE deals with reporting on him to the Australian prime minister during their next visit.

‚ÄúWhat a fucking tattletale,‚Äù Meyers laughed. ‚ÄúAlso you think you‚Äôre going to scare an Australian? They live in a country that‚Äôs mostly an unlivable desert, they have spiders the size of tennis rackets, but he‚Äôs shaking in his boots because you‚Äôre going to tell on him?‚Äù

Meyers did point out, however, that Trump‚Äôs approval rating is at an all-time low. ‚ÄúIt might feel like he‚Äôs just getting away with all this outlandish corruption and the erosion of our rights while Democrats and the media acquiesce, but most Americans are firmly opposed to this stuff,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre counting down the days until something changes.‚Äù

title: What the court decision to block deportation means for Labour‚Äôs ‚Äòone in, one out‚Äô deal with France
description:
The ruling by a judge to halt the removal of a 25-year-old Eritrean has cast doubt on the future of the programme

  • UK politics live ‚Äì latest updates
content:
The decision by a high court judge to block the deportation of a man under Labour‚Äôs ‚Äúone in one out‚Äù agreement with France has cast doubt on the future of the policy. Here, the Guardian examines the significance of the court‚Äôs decision and what it means for the removal scheme.

Why did the judge block the deportation?

Mr Justice Sheldon halted the removal after a decision came through during the court hearing that the 25-year-old Eritrean‚Äôs claims to be a victim of trafficking required further investigation.

The national referral mechanism, which identifies and assesses victims of slavery and human trafficking, invited the man to make further representations.

‚ÄúIt seems there is a serious issue to be tried with respect of the trafficking claim and whether or not the secretary of state has carried out her investigatory duties in a lawful manner,‚Äù said Sheldon. ‚ÄúIf there is a reasonable suspicion he has been trafficked that would amount to a statutory bar for removal, at least for a short period of time.‚Äù

Does this mean the whole scheme is doomed?

Comparisons are already being made with the previous government‚Äôs scheme to send asylum seekers to Rwanda being ruled unlawful by the courts but they might be premature.

The technology secretary, Liz Kendall, told Times Radio she would not comment on ‚Äúoperational details‚Äù, but said: ‚ÄúThis is one person, it is not going to undermine the fundamental basis of this deal.‚Äù

Sheldon said on Tuesday that he was ‚Äúgoing to grant a short period of interim relief‚Äù so it is still possible that the claimant could eventually be deported.

The Guardian is aware of one case in which a legal challenge lodged by an individual asylum seeker who was due to fly on Monday was unsuccessful, although he did not fly in the end.

While arguments for the claimant on Wednesday were made about the destitution he would face in France, based on the experience of other asylum seekers there, Sheldon was not persuaded by that and focused on the fact that he was a potential victim of trafficking.

By contrast, the reasons the Rwanda scheme was held to be unlawful included that it was deemed not to be a safe country for refugees, that refugees could have their applications for asylum incorrectly refused in Rwanda and that they would be at risk of return to countries where they would be in danger.

However, Emma Ginn, the director of the charity Medical Justice, said the ‚Äúvast majority‚Äù of people detained for the ‚Äúone in, one out‚Äù scheme were torture and trafficking survivors, presenting the prospect of more potential court defeats.

Will the French take victims of trafficking and torture?

Even before Tuesday‚Äôs high court decision, the viability of the ‚Äúone in, one out‚Äù agreement was called into question after plans to fly rejected asylum applicants to Paris on Monday and Tuesday were dropped.

It is believed that the flights did not happen because of concerns of French authorities that the Home Office had not provided adequate notice of the vulnerabilities of some individuals, such as victims of trafficking and torture.

According to the treaty signed last month, the UK needs to notify France in a statement ‚Äúindicating that the person to be transferred may need medical assistance or care‚Äù.

The cancelled flights have raised questions over whether France will take such individuals at all.

Why does the government not just change the law?

Given that the previous government‚Äôs Rwanda scheme was ruled unlawful and Labour‚Äôs ‚Äúone in, one out‚Äù policy has also fallen foul of the courts, could the government just use parliamentary sovereignty to change the law to prevent such outcomes?

Most of the focus at the moment has been on leaving the European convention on human rights (ECHR), which Reform UK has said it would do if elected and the Tories also seem to be moving towards, or reforming the convention, and/or its UK implementation, as Labour has discussed. While blaming the ECHR for the prevention of deportations, governments to date have not taken the drastic step of leaving, which would make the UK an international outlier with Belarus and Russia, and provoke a backlash from some quarters, both domestically and internationally.

Even if it did leave the ECHR, there are multiple other conventions with protections relevant to deportations such as the refugee convention, the torture convention and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

And even if all of these conventions were exited/suspended as Reform have suggested, putting aside what that would do for the UK‚Äôs international reputation, it would not necessarily open the door to mass deportations regardless of an individual‚Äôs circumstances.

Many rights derive from British common law and, in the absence of a politically appointed judiciary such as that in the US, judges in England and Wales would endeavour to uphold them.

title: UN warns of ‚Äògrave‚Äô concerns for fuel and food in famine-hit northern Gaza ‚Äì as it happened
description: Food and supplies running out in northern Gaza after Israel closed only crossing, UN says. This live blog is closed
content:
5.30pm BST

Closing summary

  • The United Nations voiced grave concerns on Wednesday about food and other supplies running out in northern Gaza, where hundreds of thousands of people were already experiencing famine, after Israel closed the only crossing there last week. Israel began its long-expected ground assault on Gaza City in the north on Tuesday and is stepping up efforts to empty the city of civilians by opening an additional route southwards.

  • At least 50 people were killed by Israeli strikes and gunfire across the Gaza Strip on Wednesday, including 39 in Gaza City, local health authorities said. They said the latest fatalities took the Palestinian death toll from the two-year war between Israel and Hamas past 65,000.

  • The Israeli finance minister Bezalel Smotrich has described the Gaza Strip as a ‚Äúreal estate bonanza‚Äù and said he is in talks with the US about dividing it up after the war, The Times of Israel reports. Speaking at a real estate conference in Tel Aviv, Smotrich said the destruction in Gaza is ‚Äúthe first stage in the city‚Äôs renewal‚Äù.

  • The Gaza health ministry said an Israeli drone had dropped grenades on one floor of the Rantissi children‚Äôs hospital on Wednesday. No casualties were reported but the ministry said 40 families took their children away, reports Reuters.

  • Saudi Arabia on Wednesday condemned ‚Äúin the strongest terms‚Äù the Israeli ground operation in Gaza City, a day after Israel unleashed a long-threatened ground assault on the territory. The kingdom also urged members of the UN security council to act to halt what it described as Israel‚Äôs killing, starvation and forced displacement of Palestinians, the foreign ministry said in a statement.

  • The International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) has been in touch to share an update on the situation from Gaza via a Palestinian staff member in the territory. Writing on Wednesday, Ahmed Al Waheidi said those fleeing the north for the south face ‚Äúcongested, damaged and dangerous‚Äù roads, with journeys taking ‚Äúhours‚Äù.

  • A Catholic priest in Gaza city has vowed to stay in his church compound to help look after 450 people who have taken refugee there in the face of the ground assault launched by Israel. Carlos Ferrero told RT√â they were ‚Äúscared‚Äù and many of them felt that even if they did follow Israeli instructions and evacuate to the south of the City they were in peril.

  • The European Commission has proposed suspending some of the trade parts of the EU-Israel association agreement, 18 months after Ireland and Spain asked the commission president, Ursula von der Leyen, to review the agreement in light of the war in Gaza. Following her state of the union speech last week indicating a shift at the top of the EU, the commission‚Äôs presented a proposal today.

  • The World Health Organization (WHO) said that it had supported the medical evacuations of 10 ‚Äúcritical‚Äù children from Gaza to the UK. These children were evacuated with 50 companions, the WHO said. The PA news agency reports that the UK government said that it is working to make sure families receive ‚Äúappropriate support‚Äù during their stay. More children are expected to arrive in the coming weeks.

  • The Israeli army said it has struck more than 150 targets in Gaza City since launching a major ground offensive on the Gaza Strip‚Äôs main urban hub early on Tuesday. ‚ÄúOver the past two days, the [Israeli air force] and artillery corps troops struck over 150 terror targets throughout Gaza City in support of the manoeuvring troops in the area,‚Äù the military said in a statement issued on Wednesday, reports Agence France-Presse (AFP).

  • China said on Wednesday it ‚Äúfirmly opposes‚Äù the escalation of military operations in Gaza after Israel launched a major ground assault on Gaza City. ‚ÄúChina firmly opposes Israel‚Äôs escalation of military operations in Gaza and condemns all acts that harm civilians and violate international law,‚Äù foreign ministry spokesperson Lin Jian said of the massive bombardment of Gaza City, reports Agence France-Presse (AFP).

  • Pope Leo XVI expressed solidarity with the population of Gaza on Wednesday, saying that civilians had been ‚Äúonce again‚Äù forced from their land and were living in ‚Äúunacceptable conditions‚Äù, reports Agence France-Presse (AFP). ‚ÄúI express my deep solidarity with the Palestinian people in Gaza who continue to live in fear and survive in unacceptable conditions, being forcibly displaced once again from their lands,‚Äù said the 70-year-old pope after his general audience.

5.11pm BST

Smoke rises from an Israeli airstrike in northern Gaza, as seen from the Israeli side of the border, southern Israel, earlier today.

4.38pm BST

The Israeli finance minister Bezalel Smotrich has described the Gaza Strip as a ‚Äúreal estate bonanza‚Äù and said he is in talks with the US about dividing it up after the war, The Times of Israel reports.

Speaking at a real estate conference in Tel Aviv, Smotrich said the destruction in Gaza is ‚Äúthe first stage in the city‚Äôs renewal,‚Äù adding:

We‚Äôve already started negotiations with the Americans.

The comments echo past suggestions by US president Donald Trump to redevelop Gaza as a luxury coastal area.

4.07pm BST

At least 50 people were killed by Israeli strikes and gunfire across the Gaza Strip on Wednesday, including 39 in Gaza City, local health authorities said.

They said the latest fatalities took the Palestinian death toll from the two-year war between Israel and Hamas past 65,000.

Palestinian officials and rescue workers say the true figure is likely to be higher as many people‚Äôs remains are trapped under the rubble of destroyed buildings.

3.47pm BST

A Catholic priest in Gaza city has vowed to stay in his church compound to help look after 450 people who have taken refugee there in the face of the ground assault launched by Israel.

Carlos Ferrero told RT√â they were ‚Äúscared‚Äù and many of them felt that even if they did follow Israeli instructions and evacuate to the south of the City they were in peril.

‚ÄúSome people, they say, ‚Äòwe don‚Äôt want to go. where are we going? There‚Äôs no safe place anywhere. That‚Äôs the truth,‚Äù he told RT√â in an interview with News at One‚Äôs Rachel English.

‚ÄúSometimes on the road there can be attacks. Sometimes you reach a place you don‚Äôt have a tent, you don‚Äôt know what to very bad situation, really, for everybody.‚Äù

The Holy Family Church compound in Gaza City has been bombed multiple times despite the IDF‚Äôs declaration it does not target religious sites.

Among those living in the compound are elderly people with dementia who do not understand what is going on, disabled children and sick people, Ferrero said.

‚ÄúWe are all experiencing some concern and fear. Danger is there and on top of that the current situation, it adds a little more realism to the danger. People are scared. Everybody is scared, we are all scared,‚Äù he said.

3.27pm BST

Children ran to collect evacuation order leaflets dropped by Israel‚Äôs military on 17 September, asking people to move towards the south of the Gaza Strip.

The Israeli military said it was opening an additional route for 48 hours that Palestinians could use to leave Gaza City as it stepped up efforts to empty the city of civilians.

3.12pm BST

UN warns on supplies for famine-stricken north Gaza after Israel shuts crossing

The United Nations voiced grave concerns on Wednesday about food and other supplies running out in northern Gaza, where hundreds of thousands of people were already experiencing famine, after Israel closed the only crossing there last week.

Israel began its long-expected ground assault on Gaza City in the north on Tuesday and is stepping up efforts to empty the city of civilians by opening an additional route southwards.

Hundreds of thousands of people are sheltering in the city and many are reluctant to follow Israel‚Äôs orders to move because of the dangers along the way, dire conditions, a lack of food in the southern area, and fear of permanent displacement.

‚ÄúThere are grave concerns over fuel and food stock depletion in a matter of days as there are now no direct aid entry points into northern Gaza and resupply from south to north is increasingly challenging due to mounting road congestion and insecurity,‚Äù the UN humanitarian office (OCHA) said in a statement.

The Zikim Crossing was shut on 12 September and no aid groups have been able to import supplies since, it said.

2.55pm BST

Palestinians flee toward southern Gaza along al-Rashid Street, carrying belongings on foot and in vehicles after intensified Israeli attacks and evacuation orders in the northern Gaza Strip.

2.31pm BST

Gaza health ministry accuse Israel of drone attack on children's hospital, report no casualties

The Gaza health ministry said an Israeli drone had dropped grenades on one floor of the Rantissi children‚Äôs hospital on Wednesday. No casualties were reported but the ministry said 40 families took their children away, reports Reuters.

Fikr Shalltoot, Gaza director at the UK-based charity Medical Aid for Palestinians said:

This hospital is the only specialist facility for children with cancer, kidney failure, and other life-threatening conditions ‚Äì but even these gravely ill children are not spared from relentless bombardment.

The Israeli military did not immediately respond to a request from Reuters for comment.

Updated at 2.44pm BST

2.09pm BST

The UK‚Äôs Green party leader Zack Polanski said he would be ‚Äústanding up to the bully Donald Trump and his poodle, Nigel Farage‚Äù before joining protesters in London later on Wednesday. He also accused Trump of seeking to ‚Äúwhitewash his own complicity in the genocide unfolding in Gaza‚Äù.

Polanski, who is in the lineup for a rally on Parliament Square organised by the Stop Trump Coalition, said:

Donald Trump comes to Britain seeking credibility and to whitewash his own complicity in the genocide unfolding in Gaza.

While the vast majority unite against Trump and everything he stands for, there will be one man who wants us to welcome him with open arms: Nigel Farage. Farage pretends to be a man of the people, but he‚Äôs really just a man of the super rich. Like Trump he seeks power, influence and money over all else.

Our country has a proud tradition of standing up for the underdog. Today, that means standing alongside every child in Gaza; with all those in detention camps on the borders of the United States and with each and every one of those growing up in poverty here in Britain. And standing up to the bully Donald Trump and his poodle, Nigel Farage.

1.52pm BST

Saudi Arabia on Wednesday condemned ‚Äúin the strongest terms‚Äù the Israeli ground operation in Gaza City, a day after Israel unleashed a long-threatened ground assault on the territory.

The kingdom also urged members of the UN security council to act to halt what it described as Israel‚Äôs killing, starvation and forced displacement of Palestinians, the foreign ministry said in a statement,

Israel on Tuesday started a ground offensive to seize control of Gaza‚Äôs main urban centre. There has been a wave of criticism from countries around the region including Qatar, which has been hosting and mediating ceasefire talks.

Qatar described the Israeli ground offensive as a continuation of its ‚Äúwar of genocide‚Äù against the Palestinians.

After a UN commission of inquiry concluded on Tuesday that Israel had committed
genocide in Gaza, Israel‚Äôs ambassador in Geneva, Daniel Meron, called the report ‚Äúscandalous‚Äù and ‚Äúfake‚Äù, saying it had been authored by ‚ÄúHamas proxies‚Äù.

1.31pm BST

Today‚Äôs proposal by the European Commission to suspend trade parts of the EU Israeli association would not mean Israeli goods disappearing from European supermarkets, factories, or hospitals.

If adopted by the member states, who need to agree to it under qualified majority vote system (QMV), it would merely mean goods would no longer be duty free and subject to tariffs that apply to all non-EU countries that do not have a trade agreement with the bloc.

The EU is responsible for 32% of Israel‚Äôs total trade in goods with the world, selling some ‚Ç¨16bn in 2024.

Israeli exports include everything from jet engines to pharmaceuticals including those from Teva. However, not all goods are exported under tariffs, as they are for example not imposed on pharmaceuticals under a longstanding World Trade Organization agreement.

Under the QMV system two conditions have to be met. 55% of member states need to back to the move. This means 15 out of 27 member states, but the bigger barrier is that the proposal must be supported by member states representing 65% of the total EU population.

Germany represents 18% of the EU population, France 15% and Italy 11%.

Maro≈° ≈†efƒçoviƒç, the trade commissioner, admitted that the impact of the removal of free trade access, would be ‚Äúmodest‚Äù, as he told reporters that their suggestions that tariffs would amount to an additional cost of just ‚Ç¨227m a year were ‚Äúcorrect‚Äù.

Whatever its economic consequences, it can be seen as a hugely symbolic move.

‚ÄúI would say the whole context of the decision was very political. ‚Ä¶ I think there was strong expectations that European Union have to use the tools at its disposal to address the humanitarian crisis,‚Äù he said.

EU‚Äôs top diplomat, Kaja Kallas, was also asked about whether she was confident about getting the suspension approved by the member states.

She said:

‚ÄúYou know very well, how is the situation the council, although we see that ‚Ä¶ the public opinion in member states is really shifting because the suffering in Gaza and people really want to see [this stopped].

I think we will have the discussions after these proposals are made, but I think the political lines are very much in the place where they have been so far.‚Äù

1.22pm BST

The International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) has been in touch to share an update on the situation from Gaza via a Palestinian staff member in the territory.

Writing on Wednesday, Ahmed Al Waheidi said those fleeing the north for the south face ‚Äúcongested, damaged and dangerous‚Äù roads, with journeys taking ‚Äúhours‚Äù.

In his update, he wrote:

I left my wife and children in the north yesterday and travelled six hours to come and look for somewhere we could stay in Deir al-Balah. I want to call them every five minutes and check that they are OK or not ‚Äì it is a constant fear knowing the hostilities are so close to them. The other day, a building was damaged within only fifty metres of them. The constant sound of explosions is terrifying for them, and they can feel the blast impacts ‚Äì shaking walls and shock waves of dust ‚Äì from hundreds of meters away. This is what it‚Äôs like every day for people. Many wake thinking the situation cannot get worse, but it continues to deteriorate.

When I find somewhere, I will go back and get my family, but we don‚Äôt know yet how we will move our belongings down here. There are not enough trucks for people to use, and it‚Äôs too expensive for many people. Hundreds of families are losing their homes every day, and the vast majority cannot afford the cost of being displaced and moving to the south, so they are sleeping in the streets.

My wife‚Äôs nephew was severely injured recently, and we are his last remaining family. I don‚Äôt know how we will move him from the north down to here. My mind is overwhelmed with all the decisions we have to make and the lack of choices for any of them.

The roads are congested, damaged, and dangerous, with the few working vehicles in poor condition. Journeys take hours, often on foot, with no clear destination. Elderly or sick family members arrive exhausted in the south, where even here, many are left to sleep along the roads until they can find shelter.

1.10pm BST

Towards the end of the press conference, Kallas rejected suggestions that the EU has not done enough to put pressure on Israel and insisted the public opinion has shifted on this in recent months, as reflected by the proposed measures.

‚ÄúThe proposals [are] now on the table to put more pressure on Israeli government ‚Ä¶ now it‚Äôs up to the member states to discuss [them] in the council, which is problematic, as we know of the lines.

But what it shows, really, it shows that the public opinion in all the member states has, has really shifted. And when we have the discussions, all the member states or representatives, foreign ministers, agree that the situation is untenable.

So if we all agree on this, then the question is, what do we do about this; what are the tools in our hands?

And that‚Äôs why we have proposed, then from our commission, to go with these proposals. If these do not fly, then we can find other things, if we all agree that we need to do additional steps in order to have really change on the ground.‚Äù

This concludes the press conference.

12.58pm BST

Officials from the European Commission say the proposed measure would hit more than a third of Israel‚Äôs exports to the EU worth around ‚Ç¨6bn, including key agricultural produce such as dates and nuts.

‚ÄúToday marks a critical turning point in holding Israel accountable,‚Äù said Irish foreign minister Simon Harris.

But opposition from key member states, especially Germany and Italy, means it will struggle to get the backing of enough EU countries to go through.

Israel has already urged Brussels against pushing ahead.

‚ÄúPressure through sanctions will not work,‚Äù Israeli Foreign Minister Gideon Saar wrote in a letter to Ursula von der Leyen.

12.41pm BST

Measure from Israel's largest trading partner 'appropriate and proportionate', says ≈†efƒçoviƒç

EU trade commissioner Maro≈° ≈†efƒçoviƒç is now speaking about the practical consequences of the proposed measures.

‚ÄúIn practice, this means that imports from Israel to the EU will lose the preferential access to the EU market, and that these goods will be charged duties at the level applied to any other third countries with whom the EU has no free trade agreement. We regret having to take this step. However, we believe it is both appropriate and proportionate given the ongoing humanitarian crisis in Gaza.‚Äù

≈†efƒçoviƒç said the total trade in goods amounted to ‚Ç¨42.6bn in 2024, making the EU Israel‚Äôs number one trading partner.

‚ÄúIn light of these figures and the principles at stake, the proposed partial suspension is a carefully considered response to an increasingly urgent situation,‚Äù he says.

He says the EU ‚Äúbelieves that now is the time that we must work together to end also the humanitarian crisis in Gaza.‚Äù

‚ÄúThis means unrestrained access for humanitarian aid, the immediate release of all hostages held by Hamas and an urgent ceasefire to stop the bloodshed.‚Äù

He says the member states will decide on this measure by a qualified majority.

12.37pm BST

Trade curbs not aimed 'to punish Israel', says EU foreign policy chief

The EU foreign policy chief, Kaja Kallas, has spoken more on the proposals by the European Commission to curb trade with Israel.

She said:

I want to be very clear, the aim is not to punish Israel. The aim is to improve the humanitarian situation in Gaza.

‚ÄúThe war needs to end. The suffering must stop, and all hostages must be released.‚Äù

12.32pm BST

The European Commission has proposed suspending some of the trade parts of the EU-Israel association agreement, 18 months after Ireland and Spain asked the commission president, Ursula von der Leyen, to review the agreement in light of the war in Gaza.

Following her state of the union speech last week indicating a shift at the top of the EU, the commission‚Äôs presented a proposal today.

In addition it has announced it had put bilateral support for Israel on hold with the exception of contributions to support civil society and the Yad Vashem holocaust museum.

And it has proposed sanctions on Hamas, extremist ministers and violent settlers.

In a statement, the EU said the proposal on the trade agreement follows a review of Article 2 of the deal following ‚Äúthe blockade of humanitarian aid, the intensifying of military operations and the decision of the Israeli authorities to advance the settlement plan in the so-called E1 area of the West Bank‚Äù.

The proposed suspension must be ratified by member states who are already blocking a European Commission proposal to suspend Israel from part of the Horizon European science research programme.

12.11pm BST

Brussels proposes suspension of free trade on Israeli goods

The European Commission has proposed to suspend free-trade arrangements on Israeli goods due to the war in Gaza, Reuters reports.

It comes even though the measure does not currently have sufficient support among the European Union‚Äôs member countries to pass.

The EU foreign policy chief, Kaja Kallas, also proposed a package of sanctions on two Israeli ministers, as well as violent settlers and Hamas members.

We will bring you more details as we have them.

11.51am BST

Sally Rooney, Deborah Levy, Nobel laureate Annie Ernaux and Pulitzer winner Viet Thanh Nguyen are among 20 authors urging French president Emmanuel Macron to resume a ‚Äúlifeline‚Äù programme for evacuating Palestinian writers, scholars and artists from Gaza.
