Crosetto‚Äôs comments triggered criticism from Matteo Salvini, deputy prime minister and a longtime supporter of the Russian president, Vladimir Putin, who said Italy needed to defend itself against migrants and not Russia.

Updated at 1.11pm BST

12.24pm BST

For context, the RTVE‚Äôs decision comes a day after Spanish culture minister Ernest Urtasun suggested such a move, and shortly after a group of pro-Palestinian protesters disrupted the final stage of the Vuelta a Espana cycling race in Madrid.

‚ÄúWe have to ensure that Israel does not take part in the next edition of Eurovision. Just as Ireland, Slovenia, Iceland and also the Netherlands have already done, if we do not succeed in expelling Israel, Spain should not participate,‚Äù Urtasun told Spanish public radio yesterday (Europe Live, Monday).

Related: Spain‚Äôs PM calls for Israel to be banned from sports events after Gaza protests force end to Vuelta race

12.03pm BST

Spain says it will quit 2026 Eurovision song contest if Israel takes part

Spanish broadcaster RTVE has voted on a motion to withdraw from the 2026 Eurovision song contest if Israel takes part in the event.

The motion was passed by a majority of votes on the broadcaster‚Äôs governing body, with ten votes in favour, four against, and one abstention, RTVE said in a statement.

It noted it was the first of the so-called Big Five ‚Äì France, Germany and Spain, Italy, and the UK ‚Äì to make such decision, after other countries ‚Äì including Iceland, Ireland, the Netherlands and Slovenia ‚Äì also signalled similar plans.

Related: RT√â says Ireland will boycott Eurovision if Israel is allowed to compete

RTVE said the decision will ‚Äúput more pressure‚Äù on the European Broadcasting Union‚Äôs general assembly in early December which is expected to make a decision on Israel‚Äôs participation in the event.

Updated at 12.17pm BST

11.34am BST

No delay on Russia sanctions, with discussions 'ongoing', EU spokesperson insists

The commission‚Äôs chief spokesperson also denied that there is a delay on the latest round of sanctions on Russia.

‚ÄúWe did see reports about the delay, but the fact is that we never announced a concrete date, so we don‚Äôt see any delay, right? Discussions are ongoing in order to have a solid package to be put forward as soon as it is ready,‚Äù Pinho said.

Earlier on Tuesday, EU officials briefed reporters, including from Politico and Reuters, that there will be a delay in presenting the new package, which had been expected to be presented on Wednesday.

11.30am BST

EU will adopt new sanctions against Israel tomorrow

EU commissioners will on Wednesday agree to impose new sanctions against Israel over its war in Gaza, a spokesperson for the commission said on Tuesday.

‚ÄúTomorrow, commissioners will be adopting a package of measures on Israel,‚Äù spokesperson Paula Pinho said, as reported by Reuters.

‚ÄúSpecifically, a proposal to suspend certain trade provisions in the agreements between the EU and Israel.‚Äù

EU foreign affairs spokesperson Anouar El Anouni warned that the military intervention will lead ‚Äúto more destruction, more death, more displacement‚Äù and ‚Äúwill aggravate an already catastrophic humanitarian situation.‚Äù

Updated at 11.43am BST

11.08am BST

Germany, Sweden criticise Israeli ground assault on Gaza City

Elsewhere, German and Swedish foreign ministers criticised Israel‚Äôs move on Gaza City, with Johann Wadephul calling it ‚Äúcompletely wrong‚Äù and calling for urgent talks on a ceasefire and hostage release instead.

‚ÄúThe renewed offensive towards Gaza City is... the completely wrong path,‚Äù he said at a press conference with his Swedish counterpart, Maria Malmer Stenergard.

Stenergard was also critical of the move, saying:

‚ÄúWe, from the Swedish side, are extremely worried, and we have been very clear from the very beginning when these plans were presented that any change by force of territory would be a breach of international law, and we are extremely worried about the situation in Gaza.‚Äù

Commenting on the UN findings today that Israel has committed genocide in Gaza, she said:

‚ÄúWe do have an obligation to stop and prevent genocide from happening, and that is why Sweden is one of the biggest providers of humanitarian aid to Gaza.

That is why we want to put more pressure on the Israeli government, for instance by stopping the trade part of the Association Agreement, or also putting sanctions on extremist ministers in the Israeli government.

10.36am BST

Ukrainian man tried for alleged Nord Stream sabotage ordered to be extradited to Germany

A Ukrainian arrested in Italy last month over the 2022 sabotage of the Nord Stream gas pipelines from Russia to Europe must be extradited to Germany, a court in Bologna ruled.

The man, identified as Serhii K, has denied being part of a cell which placed explosives on the pipeline and will appeal against the extradition ruling at Italy‚Äôs supreme court, his lawyer Nicola Canestrini told AFP.

10.21am BST

'If you've got drones putting Polish lives at risk, Nato will ... take them out,' UK defence secretary says

Defence and security editor

John Healey, the UK defence secretary, said Nato was ‚Äúresponding with unity and strength‚Äù to the threats and that Typhoons would be ready to attack Russian drones flying over Nato countries if required to do so.

‚ÄúIf you‚Äôve got drones that are putting Polish lives at risk, then Nato will take the action to take them out,‚Äù Healey said, adding the Typhoons were part of a broader mission ‚Äúto defend Nato airspace‚Äù.

Over the weekend, Romania became the second Nato ally in eastern Europe to detect a Russian drone crossing into its airspace in a week ‚Äì and Healey said the Typhoons mission would extend operations to the country if deemed necessary.

He said: ‚ÄúThey are deployed as part of the Nato Eastern Sentry air policing. What Nato decides to and where it decides to deploy them will be for Nato. That‚Äôs part of our contribution to the alliance.‚Äù

There was no further update on whether the UK believed that the Russian drone incursion into Poland was deliberate.

Healey said: ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no firm confirmation on intent, but in the end that‚Äôs not the point. It‚Äôs still reckless, it‚Äôs still dangerous.‚Äù It was, he added, ‚Äústraight out of the [Vladimir] Putin playbook‚Äù.

10.16am BST

Back to Ukraine, the UK has announced last night that RAF Typhoon jets will be deployed within days to shoot down drones over Poland and other Nato allies in eastern Europe if necessary.

The move comes just days after last week‚Äôs incursion of 19 uncrewed Russian aircraft into Poland.

Our defence and security editor Dan Sabbagh has the details on how the operation will work.

9.52am BST

'For Europe's survival, we must do what has not been done before,' EU's Draghi says

Summing up his speech, Draghi says that ‚Äúin substance, the more reforms, and this is a point I made some times, the more we push [for] reforms, the more private capital will step up and the less public money we will need.‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course, this path will break longstanding taboos, but the rest of the world has already broken theirs. For Europe‚Äôs survival, we must do what has not been done before, and refuse to be held back by self imposed limits,‚Äù he says.

He stresses the EU needs to ‚Äúmove beyond broad strategies and back-loaded timelines,‚Äù and need ‚Äúconcrete dates and deliverables.‚Äù

‚ÄúEuropean citizens are asking that their leaders raise their eyes from their daily concerns towards their common European destiny and grasp the scale of the challenge.

Only unity of intent and urgency of response will show that they are ready to meet extraordinary times with extraordinary action.‚Äù

9.42am BST

EU seen by companies as 'failing to match the speed of change elsewhere,' Draghi says as he urges EU to move faster on competitiveness

Well, Mario Draghi ‚Äì of the Draghi report ‚Äì is speaking now and he is not exactly as positive as von der Leyen.

He talks about the need for the EU to move faster, be more agile, and match the pace of change elsewhere.

He says that having his plan means that ‚ÄúEurope‚Äôs citizens and companies value the diagnosis, the clear priorities and the action plans, but they also express growing frustration‚Äù with the pace of change.

‚ÄúThey are disappointed by how slowly the EU moves. They see us failing to match the speed of change elsewhere. They are ready to act, but fear governments have not grasped the gravity of the moment,‚Äù he says.

He adds that ‚Äútoo often, excuses are made for our slowness,‚Äù with some portraying it as the EU‚Äôs strength or respect for the rule of law.

‚ÄúI think that‚Äôs complacency. Competitors in US and China are far less constrained even when acting within the law. To carry on as usual is to resign ourselves to falling behind,‚Äù he warns.

‚ÄúA different path demands new speed, scale and intensity. It means acting together, not fragmenting our efforts. It means focusing resources where impact is greatest. It means delivering results within months, not years,‚Äù he argues.

On AI, he also strikes a more cautions tone, saying that it ‚Äúdepends on the orchestration of at least four other technologies‚Äù in cloud, supercomputing, cybersecurity and fibre satellites.

He says that Europe is falling behind the US and China on large foundation models, and sees lower AI adoption.

He stresses that ‚Äúmore ambition is needed‚Äù to ‚Äúremove barriers to scaling up new technologies,‚Äù as he calls for more support from member states to move faster.

Draghi also takes about the AI Act being ‚Äúanother source of uncertainty,‚Äù suggesting that the next stage of codes of practice on high risk AI systems should be ‚Äúpaused until we better understand the drawbacks‚Äù as he called for ‚Äúex post‚Äù assessment to drive enforcement.

On industrial policies needed to respond to the rise of economic nationalism and protectionism, he says:

‚ÄúStates are using every tool at their disposal to advance their interests. So far, Europe‚Äôs response has fallen into two traps, uncoordinated national efforts or blind faith that market force will build new structures. The first can never deliver scale. The second is impossible when others distort markets and tilt the level playing field.‚Äù

Ouch, ouch, ouch.

9.10am BST

EU's von der Leyen praises bloc's progress on competitiveness

As I mentioned earlier, the EU‚Äôs von der Leyen is speaking now in Brussels on ‚Äúone year after the Draghi report.‚Äù

Painting a rather rosy picture, she argues that Europe ‚Äúis not only a challenger, but a leader in many fields that will define that race‚Äù on innovation, including computing power and AI adoption.

She insists that Europe ‚Äúis not playing catch up‚Äù like it was during the rise of the Internet, but is ‚Äúamong the frontrunners.‚Äù

But on a slightly more critical tone, she says that Europe ‚Äúneeds to capitalise on our strengths‚Äù as she pointed out that the bloc‚Äôs ‚Äúsingle market is far from being completed‚Äù and this needs to change to help companies grow.

‚ÄúIt should not be easier to find a fortune across an ocean than across a European border, and we have started to address these barriers,‚Äù she says, stressing plans to progress reforms by 2028.

She also talks about the progress on cleaner energy, even as she admits that ‚Äúour energy prices remain still far too high, too volatile, too disparate across Europe‚Äù with more to be done on interconnectors and grids across the continent.

Von der Leyen also talks about the need to reduce Europe‚Äôs dependencies, particularly on China. ‚ÄúWith the right policies, we can shore up our security,‚Äù she says.

I‚Äôll keep monitoring her speech for key lines.

9.02am BST

More than 3,500 drones launched at Ukraine this month, Zelenskyy says

Ukraine‚Äôs Zelenskyy said that Russia has launched more than 3,500 drones and nearly 190 missiles against Ukraine so far this month.

‚ÄúThere have also been provocations against our partners,‚Äù he said on X, refering to recent Russian drone incursions into Poland and Romania.

‚ÄúThis is precisely the kind of aerial terror against which Ukraine is calling for joint defence ‚Äì so that no one has to scramble combat aircraft in haste and feel Russia‚Äôs pressure on their borders.‚Äù

He added:

‚ÄúNow is the time to implement the joint protection of our European skies with a multi-layered air defense system.

All the technologies for this are already in place. What is needed are investments and determination ‚Äì strong action.‚Äù

Zelenskyy also offered an update on overnight attacks on Zaporizhzhia, which he said injured 13, including two children. In the Mykolaiv region, one person was killed after a strike on what he called ‚Äúan ordinary farm.‚Äù

8.49am BST

Morning opening: Welcome back to Europe, Mr Trump

Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelenskyy has called for US president Donald Trump to take ‚Äúa clear position‚Äù on Russia, including sanctions and security guarantees for Ukraine.

In an interview with Sky News, published overnight, he said it was the missing piece to progress peace talks as he urged Trump to take ‚Äústrong personal steps‚Äù to ‚Äústop Putin.‚Äù

He stressed that he hoped UK prime minister Keir Starmer could gain more clarity from Trump during his state visit to the UK, beginning tonight.

We may hear from Trump himself later as he makes his way to London.

Separately, US state secretary Marco Rubio told reporters in Israel that Trump would ‚Äúprobably‚Äù meet with Zelenskyy again during next week‚Äôs UN general assembly in New York.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs going to keep trying. If peace is possible, he wants to achieve it,‚Äù Rubio said.

Elsewhere, the EU will be looking at the progress it‚Äôs made on competitiveness, a year on from the Draghi report that became an obligatory point of reference in all discussions on the bloc‚Äôs economy. EU‚Äôs Ursula von der Leyen and the man himself are up shortly.

It‚Äôs Tuesday, 16 September 2025, it‚Äôs Jakub Krupa here, and this is Europe Live.

Good morning.

title: ‚ÄòThis country‚Äôs gonna fall on its face. There‚Äôs nobody coming to save us‚Äô: Boston punks Dropkick Murphys take on Maga
description: Videos of frontman Ken Casey confronting rightwing provocateurs at the band‚Äôs gigs have gone viral, attracting new fans and new safety worries. He wants to lower the temperature ‚Äì and see other bands speaking out
content:
Backstage at the Rock la Cauze festival in Victoriaville, Canada, where Boston punk-rock institution Dropkick Murphys are headlining, founding bassist/singer Ken Casey is experiencing an uncharacteristic moment of anxiety.

‚ÄúWe have concerns about going back over the border tonight,‚Äù he says, gravely ‚Äì not for the illicit reasons touring musicians usually fear border crossings, but because Casey‚Äôs regular on stage rants against Donald Trump have gone viral. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not worried about being arrested,‚Äù he adds. ‚ÄúBut we have a show in New York tomorrow. Are we gonna get harassed or held up? We used to come over that border and they‚Äôd be, ‚ÄòDropkicks! Come right through!‚Äô But what‚Äôs it going to be like now?‚Äù

By ‚Äúnow‚Äù, Casey means during the second Trump presidency, which has brought the political element always present within Dropkick Murphys‚Äô bolshie, Pogues and Clash-influenced bruisers to the fore. The group‚Äôs resistance has found its sharpest expression at their shows, where their anthem First Class Loser is accompanied by videos depicting Trump and former chum Jeffrey Epstein, while Casey‚Äôs skirmishes with a vocal minority of Maga Dropkicks fans in the mosh pit have lit up social media. He admits these fans often provoke the worst in him. ‚ÄúHow do you know if someone‚Äôs in a cult? They hold up a hat all fuckin‚Äô night,‚Äù he rages in one clip.

‚ÄúPeople tell me, ‚ÄòYou didn‚Äôt use-ta soapbox like this‚Äô,‚Äù he says on our video call, gathering steam. ‚ÄúWell, we didn‚Äôt use-ta be in the midst of an authoritarian takeover!‚Äù

Dropkick Murphys are still commanding big blue-collar crowds as they approach their 30th anniversary in 2026. Over the years they‚Äôve scored numerous US Top 10 albums, Bruce Springsteen collaborations and a platinum-seller in the form of civic anthem I‚Äôm Shipping Up to Boston, boosted by its appearance in Martin Scorsese‚Äôs The Departed. But their value system, Casey says, hasn‚Äôt changed since the now seven-strong band formed with the aim ‚Äúto be a voice for working people‚Äù. Class and the labour movement are key to the 56-year-old‚Äôs identity. ‚ÄúMy father died when I was very young. I was raised by my grandfather, a labour organiser who instilled in me the value of a union. In the Boston suburb where I was raised, everyone owed their lives to a union job. It put a roof over our head.‚Äù

The Boston of Casey‚Äôs youth was heavily Irish-American. ‚ÄúThe English love to call us ‚Äòplastic paddies‚Äô, but I‚Äôve never thought of myself as Irish ‚Äì I‚Äôm Boston Irish, the people that fought against the most Wasp-y, keep-the-Irish-down place that ever existed,‚Äù he says, referring to how Irish refugees fleeing the great famine of 19th-century were targeted by anti-Catholic, anti-immigrant groups and scorned by the English Protestant Puritans who had settled America. ‚ÄúTo go from those trenches to positions of power in city hall, on the railroad and in the utility companies led to my generation being able to have the middle-class life.‚Äù

He pauses for a second, but he‚Äôs not finished: Casey would make a great labour organiser himself. ‚ÄúWhen that‚Äôs your story, you need to be willing to aid the culture that‚Äôs coming next. One immigrant culture can‚Äôt close the door behind them, especially not in America. We‚Äôre all immigrants here.‚Äù

A tearaway in his youth, Casey quit drink and drugs before he reached 21, ‚Äúbecause otherwise I‚Äôd be in prison,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúI had a big problem as a teen.‚Äù He ploughed his energies into the hardcore punk scene surrounding Boston venue the Rathskeller, AKA the Rat. ‚ÄúPunk-rock was the soundtrack to my friggin‚Äô mayhem. I was a rebellious kid, I liked the underdog vibe.‚Äù In 1996, now booking shows at the Rat, a co-worker bet him $30 he ‚Äúdidn‚Äôt have the balls to start a band on three weeks‚Äô notice‚Äù. Never one to back down from a wager, Casey formed Dropkick Murphys.

His identity was stamped all over the group. Before they even used Celtic instrumentation ‚Äì the Dropkicks are the rare punk band to field a bagpiper ‚Äì he says the embryonic Dropkicks ‚Äúsounded like [1960s Irish folk group] the Clancy Brothers meets the Ramones ‚Äì the delivery, the melodies, the lyrical content. It just naturally poured out of me.‚Äù

Their beginnings were hardscrabble: pressing their own singles, booking their own shows and touring in an old Boston transit bus, for reasons of poverty and pride. ‚ÄúWe peeled the roof off under a low bypass,‚Äù he grins. ‚ÄúWe toured for two more years with that roof open like a convertible. When it rained, I held an umbrella over the driver.‚Äù

By the 21st century, they had become staples of the US punk-rock circuit, their annual St Patrick‚Äôs Day shows among Boston‚Äôs hottest tickets, performing and recording with their heroes. ‚ÄúWe play Billy Bragg‚Äôs There Is Power in a Union over the PA every night before we go on stage,‚Äù Casey says. ‚ÄúHe opened our St Patrick‚Äôs show last year with it and then played Worker‚Äôs Song with us. Afterwards, he said, ‚ÄòI felt like I was in the fuckin‚Äô Clash for three minutes!‚Äô‚Äù Springsteen, another member of the Dropkicks‚Äô extended family, recorded their Rose Tattoo for a charity single after the Boston Marathon bombing, and sang Peg O‚Äô My Heart with Dropkicks in Boston, ‚Äúback when my grandmother Peg was still alive‚Äù, says Casey. ‚ÄúHe came on with her for the encore ‚Äì we had to pry her off Bruce‚Äôs arm to get her off the stage. I‚Äôm almost shocked a guy of that level was so down-to-earth. But he‚Äôs always had an affinity with punk. Bruce still walks the talk.‚Äù

‚ÄúWalking the talk‚Äù matters to the Dropkicks; their merch is made in the US by union-approved manufacturers, while their Claddagh Fund supports non-profit organisations across Boston. ‚ÄúWe were pretty beloved in our city, whether people liked our music or not, because we gave a lot back to the community,‚Äù Casey says. Not any more, however. ‚ÄúNow a lot of people in my circles say ‚ÄòFuck Dropkick Murphys‚Äô,‚Äù he adds, lantern jaw clenching. ‚ÄúAlthough never to my face. They despise me and the band.‚Äù

I tell Maga friends of mine: Trump wouldn‚Äôt piss on you if you were on fire

It‚Äôs clear that, for Casey, the political is personal. His sense of betrayal regarding ‚Äúthe many rank-and-file union members who are now Trump voters‚Äù is palpable. ‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt think Trump‚Äôs coming for the unions, but he‚Äôs coming for the unions, trust me. I tell Maga friends of mine: Trump wouldn‚Äôt piss on you if you were on fire. It‚Äôs about total control for the rich. It‚Äôs class war.‚Äù

What is the magic spell Trump has managed to cast over a demographic who were until recently, Casey says, ‚Äúin lockstep with Dropkicks‚Äô beliefs‚Äù? ‚ÄúTrump offered them a chance to say out loud things people used to have to whisper to their friends,‚Äù Casey spits. ‚ÄúRacism, cruelty, jokes about disabilities. A lot of white people in America believed whites will not be in control any more, especially after Obama. This is their last, desperate grasp to hold control.‚Äù

The Dropkicks have met this grim moment with records that have transformed their previously cartoonish riot music into something more sober, biting and heartfelt. Two acoustic albums ‚Äì 2022‚Äôs This Machine Still Kills Fascists and 2023‚Äôs Okemah Rising ‚Äì set unrecorded Woody Guthrie polemics to their music. ‚ÄúWoody‚Äôs grandson Cole told his mom Nora, ‚ÄòGrandpa would‚Äôve liked these guys‚Äô,‚Äù Casey beams proudly. ‚ÄúIt made us better musicians, doing it all acoustic. But that left us with a hunger to go electric and be a punk-rock band again.‚Äù Which brings us to this year‚Äôs For the People, which opens with Who‚Äôll Stand With Us? A key lyric: ‚ÄúThe working people fuel the engine / While you yank the chain.‚Äù

In another viral clip from a recent show, Casey bets a fan in a Maga shirt $100 that it wasn‚Äôt manufactured in the US; it was, inevitably, manufactured in Nicaragua, and Casey swapped the offending garment for a union-made Dropkicks T-shirt.

‚ÄúIf America is ever going to go back to some semblance of normal, we have to bring the temperature down, we need to be able to talk to each other,‚Äù Casey says, referencing that night. ‚ÄúI talked to that guy afterwards, and he said, ‚ÄòI don‚Äôt let politics get in the way of family, and I consider you family‚Äô. I could have jumped down his throat, but he seemed open to reason.‚Äù He pauses. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs rare for Maga, though. Other days, I‚Äôm like, ‚ÄòFuck this, I don‚Äôt even want to know these people, if this is how they think and behave‚Äô. Do I want to have a dialogue with these people? No. I‚Äôm just hoping the fever will break. I don‚Äôt need them to have a ‚Äòcome to Jesus‚Äô moment on the difference between right and wrong ‚Äì I just need them not to support what‚Äôs happening.‚Äù

Does he fear blowback for his outspokenness, like that suffered by Stephen Colbert ‚Äì or worse?

Related: Deftones singer Chino Moreno: ‚ÄòI‚Äôve got hundreds of drawings of myself in my house‚Äô

‚ÄúUnlike Stephen, we have no parent company, so we can say what we want,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúRegarding our safety ‚Ä¶ whatever,‚Äù he snarls, disdainfully. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll never have a security guard or anything like that. But you gotta keep your head on a swivel a little bit. Back in the day, we always had a Nazi element gunning for us, but you could see them coming. Now you don‚Äôt know who‚Äôs who. I‚Äôm not sure what‚Äôs keeping other people quiet, though, especially in punk-rock. Where‚Äôd everyone go? They had the balls to speak out against Bush back in the day. But Bush didn‚Äôt have an army of trolls that come after you. Speaking out against Bush wasn‚Äôt going to cost you half your fanbase, potentially.‚Äù

In his darker moments, Casey reckons ‚Äúwithin a year, this country‚Äôs gonna fall on its face, and people are gonna feel the pain: recession, inflation, unemployment. There‚Äôs nobody coming to save us.‚Äù He says he feels ‚Äúno excitement or happiness‚Äù in the group‚Äôs anti-Trump screeds winning them newfound fame. ‚ÄúBut maybe there‚Äôs a slight sense of validation,‚Äù he adds. ‚ÄúI talk to the fans every night. One night, an immigrant told me, ‚ÄòI moved here, and my partner is American, we have children, and I live in fear of being deported. My own friends have turned on me, they say I‚Äôm taking American jobs.‚Äô He was actually in tears at the end. But he said, ‚ÄòI feel like someone is speaking on my behalf‚Äô. From the earliest days of this band, we wanted to be involved in something that mattered. So we are. I wish it was a different subject and not quite so important, but ‚Ä¶‚Äù

He sighs. Maybe the border tonight will be a shitshow, but it won‚Äôt change how the Dropkicks operate in this darkest of moments. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre sticking our neck out and getting a lot of negative attention,‚Äù he adds. ‚ÄúBut if we don‚Äôt do it now, it might be too late.‚Äù

‚Ä¢ For the People is out now on Dummy Luck Music/PIAS. Dropkick Murphys‚Äô European tour begins 15 October at Alcatraz, Milan

title: Charlie Kirk suspect allegedly took responsibility for killing in online post
description: Discord platform confirms message to friends from suspect, 22, who will be arraigned on Tuesday
content:
The 22-year-old suspect in the killing of the rightwing provocateur Charlie Kirk last week appeared to take responsibility for the fatal shooting in a message to friends on Discord, the chat platform has confirmed.

‚ÄúHey guys, I have bad news for you all,‚Äù said a message from an account allegedly belonging to the suspect, Tyler Robinson, mere hours before his arrest the day after Kirk‚Äôs killing on 10 September at Utah Valley University (UVU). ‚ÄúIt was me at UVU yesterday. i‚Äôm sorry for all of this.‚Äù

The messages were first reported by the Washington Post on Monday. CBS News then reported a Discord spokesperson then confirmed the messages.

The news of the messages surfaced as Robinson was expected to appear in a Utah court on Tuesday to face formal charges that could include capital murder, which is punishable by the death penalty.

Robinson was arrested after a frantic manhunt and now formal charging documents are set to be made public after a later morning news conference by the Utah county prosecutor, Jeff Gray.

Robinson is also scheduled to make his first court appearance later on Tuesday, at which he will be arraigned. Federal charges could follow, according to the deputy US attorney general, Todd Blanche. The appearance will probably be by video.

The charges will come as investigators continue to gather evidence against the suspect and to find out whether he acted alone or as part of a wider conspiracy. Federal hate crime charges could also follow.

Related: Charlie Kirk shooting suspect had ‚Äòvery different ideology‚Äô than conservative family, Utah governor says

A motive has not been revealed by Utah officials, but JD Vance has said ‚Äúleftwing extremism‚Äù is ‚Äúpart of the reason‚Äù Kirk was killed, without providing details on any supporting evidence.

Late Monday on Fox News, the FBI director, Kash Patel, claimed the suspect had allegedly justified his actions by saying ‚Äúsome hatred cannot be negotiated with‚Äù and referred to apparent text messages.

‚ÄúI will say what was found in terms of information, a text message exchange, where the suspect specifically stated he had the opportunity to take out Charlie Kirk and he was gonna do that,‚Äù Patel told the outlet.

Despite the messages attributed to Robinson on the platform, Discord said an internal investigation found ‚Äúno evidence that the suspect planned this incident or promoted violence‚Äù on the platform.

Reportedly, in the discussion, at least three friends asked Robinson if he was the shooter, saying the photos released by the FBI resembled him. Robinson did not seem to refute it.

In one exchange, law enforcement sources reportedly told CBS, one friend told Robinson he should avoid McDonald‚Äôs, an apparent reference to Luigi Mangione, the man accused of killing the UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson in December. Mangione was apprehended in a McDonald‚Äôs restaurant after a manhunt.

‚ÄúWhatever you do don‚Äôt go to a mcdonalds anytime soon,‚Äù the friend wrote, according to the law enforcement sources.

The user believed to be Robinson, responded: ‚ÄúBetter also get rid of this manifesto and exact copy rifle I have lying around.‚Äù

The exchanges concluded shortly before Robinson was arrested. ‚Äúim surrendering through a sheriff friend in a few moments, thanks for all the good times and laughs, you‚Äôve all been so amazing, thank you all for everything,‚Äù he reportedly wrote.

Robinson indeed surrendered the day after Kirk‚Äôs killing to authorities with the help of a family friend who was a law enforcement official, authorities have said.

On Monday, Patel revealed that DNA matching the suspect was found on a towel used to wrap the rifle believed to be used in the shooting and on a screwdriver found at the rooftop perch Robinson allegedly used to fire the fatal shot.

Separately, the FBI co-deputy director Dan Bongino told Fox News on Monday evening that Robinson was alleged to have had an ‚Äúobsession‚Äù with Kirk, citing the suspect‚Äôs digital footprint appeared to have exhibited ‚Äúmultiple warning signs‚Äù.

‚ÄúI believe co-workers stated he had detached himself when the topic of politics came up and walked away,‚Äù Bongino said, adding that the bureau was looking at whether they had prior knowledge but did not alert authorities.

‚ÄúDid they ‚Ä¶ hear it and think it was a joke? That is what we‚Äôre trying to find out now,‚Äù Bongino said. ‚ÄúIf there is a larger network here, we will get that out to the public as soon as we can.‚Äù

Related: Suspect in Charlie Kirk shooting lived in quiet Utah town: ‚ÄòNo different than my family‚Äô

Utah‚Äôs governor, Spencer Cox, has vowed to seek the death penalty for Kirk‚Äôs alleged killer but the state‚Äôs attorney general, Derek Brown, has said prosecutors are ‚Äústill collecting facts‚Äù.

Utah law requires one of four ‚Äúaggravating factors‚Äù for prosecutors to seek the death penalty in murder cases, including having multiple victims, targeting a police officer or public official, committing the crime in addition to another serious felony such as kidnapping, or being ‚Äúespecially heinous, atrocious, cruel or exceptionally depraved‚Äù.

‚ÄúI can say that it‚Äôs obviously part of Utah law,‚Äù Brown said in an interview with the Salt Lake Tribune. ‚ÄúIt is an option here, but it‚Äôs not something that I can talk about in terms of whether that will play a role in this case.‚Äù

But Brown noted that charges could be amended and any decision to seek the death penalty could come ‚Äúat some point in the future‚Äù.

title: Southport killer thought to have viewed teen stabbing footage shortly before attack
description: ‚ÄòSobering and concerning‚Äô that Axel Rudakubana had searched X for Australia knife attack, inquiry told
content:
A lawyer said it was ‚Äúsobering and concerning‚Äù that the Southport attacker probably viewed footage on social media of a stabbing in Australia by a teenage boy just 40 minutes before carrying out his own crimes.

An inquiry is being held into the circumstances and events leading up to the attack by Axel Rudakubana, then 17, on 29 July 2024 in which he murdered three young girls and attempted to murder eight children and two adults.

On Tuesday, Nicholas Moss KC, counsel to the inquiry, outlined what would be explored and the questions that would be asked during the course of the inquiry, being held at Liverpool town hall.

Moss said a notable feature of the ‚Äúextremely cowardly‚Äù attack was that it was ‚Äúspecifically targeting women and girls‚Äù.

He said the inquiry would establish a timeline of Rudakubana‚Äôs history and ‚Äúinteractions with various state systems including criminal justice, education, social care and healthcare‚Äù.

Questions will also be asked of Rudakubana‚Äôs parents and of the social media companies Meta and X.

Moss referred to Rudakubana as AR throughout his submission, and described him as a ‚Äúprolific internet user‚Äù.

The inquiry heard that the teenager had deleted his browsing history on his laptop before carrying out his crimes. But evidence showed he used another tablet to search on X for a knife attack by a teenage boy on a bishop in Australia.

The search led him to posts on X likely to have shown the actual act of stabbing, Moss said.

‚ÄúThe inquiry has made a statement request of X about the fact that the act of a stabbing would have been viewable on its platform apparently to a 17-year-old boy,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúIt might, perhaps, be thought to be both sobering and concerning, in terms of online harms, that almost the last thing AR did before committing these dreadful crimes was to search for, and possibly view, material on Twitter in relation to a stabbing carried out by another boy aged under 18.‚Äù

Moss said Meta, which owns Instagram, and X had been asked for ‚Äúinformation about AR‚Äôs use of their platforms and we await their substantive responses‚Äù.

Rudakubana travelled by taxi from his home in Banks to a Taylor Swift-themed yoga and dance class for children in Southport, where he committed his crimes. The inquiry was shown the pink-coloured advert for the class, which was ‚Äúbound to appeal more to girls than boys‚Äù, Moss said.

Apart from one man injured in the attack, it was a ‚Äúnotable feature‚Äù that all the other victims were female, he continued.

The killer was jailed for life with a minimum term of 52 years in January at Liverpool crown court, after admitting the murders and attempted murders, described in court as ‚Äúsadistic‚Äù.

One part of the inquiry will be Rudakubana‚Äôs internet use and purchase of weapons, posing as an adult and using a false name. Moss said: ‚ÄúAR‚Äôs purchase of weapons is important because it will highlight vulnerabilities in the law against the purchase of knives, crossbows and machetes.‚Äù

Rudakubana also bought seeds through Amazon, which he used to make a ‚Äúcrude preparation of ricin‚Äù, Moss said.

He said the inquiry had requested detailed statements from Rudakubana‚Äôs parents ‚Äúand will seek to explore their awareness of AR‚Äôs online orders and the items that AR stored in his bedroom and the living room of their home‚Äù.

A central theme of the inquiry would be which bodies or agencies ‚Äútook ownership‚Äù for intervening to address the risks that Rudakubana had demonstrated in his behaviour before the crimes.

Before Moss spoke, the chair of the inquiry, Sir Adrian Fulford, promised to do everything ‚Äúhumanly possible‚Äù to answer the questions of bereaved families and victims.

On Monday, the inquiry heard harrowing testimony from the parents of the three murdered girls ‚Äì Elsie Dot Stancombe, seven, Bebe King, six, and Alice da Silva Aguiar, nine.

Impact evidence has also been heard from families of the other children present on the day and the injured adults.

The inquiry continues.

title: Dad‚Äôs part in Pink Floyd‚Äôs free-form mayhem on Jugband Blues | Brief letters
description: Salvation Army ensemble | Giving way | Cornish conundrum | Nuclear fast-track fears | Rejects UK
content:
While Jugband Blues didn‚Äôt get into Alex Petridis‚Äôs top 10 Pink Floyd songs (Ranked!, 12 September), I was pleased to see it at No 11 in his top 20 list online. Petridis describes a Salvation Army band erupting into ‚Äúfree-form mayhem‚Äù as a counterpoint to Syd Barrett‚Äôs ‚Äúdead-eyed voice‚Äù. My father, George Whittingham, and his lifelong friend, Maurice Cooper, were part of the ensemble responsible for that sonic mayhem. Not bad for someone who recently celebrated his 99th birthday, and for Maurice, who is 96. Perhaps it‚Äôs time for them to get the band back together?
Ian Whittingham
Golden Cross, East Sussex

In New Zealand, the signs say ‚ÄúMerge like a zip‚Äù, and in Denmark, the white line between a slip road and the main carriageway disappears, indicating that no one has right of way and you‚Äôre expected to be nice.
Deirdre Burrell
Mortimer, Berkshire
