title: Chadwick Boseman play about police brutality to receive UK premiere in London
description: Deep Azure, written by the Black Panther star in response to the death of a fellow college student, will open at Sam Wanamaker Playhouse next year
content:
A play by the Black Panther star Chadwick Boseman, who died of cancer aged 43 in 2020, is to receive its UK premiere next year.

Deep Azure was written by Boseman in response to the death of Prince Jones, his fellow college student at Washington DC‚Äôs Howard University, who was killed in 2000 by a police officer. The play was first performed in 2005 in the US and will be staged at the Sam Wanamaker Playhouse in London in February, directed by Tristan Fynn-Aiduenu.

Related: ‚ÄòYou are all the Black Panther‚Äô: the electric theatre of Chadwick Boseman

Fynn-Aiduenu described the play as ‚Äúincredibly poignant in speaking about the injustices of police brutality and the unwinding nature of grief, but also the gorgeous brilliance of our Black Souls and exploring every hue they can express on a stage‚Äù. He said that Boseman‚Äôs love of Shakespeare and hip-hop combined in a ‚Äúlayered, ghostly epic that I have been given the privilege and duty to fully realise‚Äù.

Boseman was best known for his performance in the title role of Marvel‚Äôs Black Panther, and was posthumously nominated for an Oscar for his performance in Ma Rainey‚Äôs Black Bottom, based on August Wilson‚Äôs play. But before he rose to fame as an actor, he had shown himself to be a promising playwright.

The director Derrick Sanders, another Howard University alumnus who commissioned Deep Azure, told the Guardian in 2020 that Boseman took the elements of hip-hop culture ‚Äì graffiti, DJing, rapping, breakdancing ‚Äì ‚Äúand combined them into a narrative form. The storytelling would move it in and out of hip-hop, almost as a precursor to Hamilton.‚Äù

Boseman studied Shakespeare at Oxford University with the British American Drama Academy in 1998. He had wanted to make a film of Deep Azure before his Hollywood career exploded. Daniel Banks, who directed the play at the Folger theatre in Washington DC, said that it was ‚Äúwritten as a ritual of community healing‚Äù. The killing of Jones by an undercover police officer in Virginia in 2000 was also covered by the author Ta-Nehisi Coates in the 2015 book Between the World and Me. In 2006, after a civil trial, damages were awarded to Jones‚Äôs young daughter for his wrongful death.

Deep Azure will run from 7 February to 11 April in the Sam Wanamaker Playhouse, the indoor candlelit venue run by Shakespeare‚Äôs Globe. It will be performed alongside a new production of The Tempest (17 January to 12 April) directed by Tim Crouch, who will play Prospero alongside Naomi Wirthner (How to Train Your Dragon) as Ariel.

Crouch is the creator of a series of acclaimed Shakespearean dramas presented from the perspective of the plays‚Äô minor characters, including I, Caliban and I, Banquo. He said he had ‚Äúbeen given the keys to the most interesting theatre in London. The spaces at the Globe are not anonymous black boxes that try to disappear as soon as the play begins. They are companions to any work that happens in them; good companions which support and contribute to the stories that they house.‚Äù

title: Yes, British democracy is under threat ‚Äì from Musk and his billions, not desperate people on small boats | Arwa Mahdawi
description: Tesla‚Äôs boss has already done his best to destabilise the US, Canada and Germany. Keir Starmer needs to push back
content:
The year is 2125 and an AI-powered hologram of Elon Musk is CEO of The World, Inc. Nation states are defunct and ‚Äúcitizens‚Äù an outdated concept. Now people function more like non-voting shareholders of heavily armed corporations. Anyone who dares to criticise Lord Musk is sentenced to death in a burning Tesla.

This isn‚Äôt my poor attempt at science fiction (apart from some creative licence around the AI Musk and Tesla executions). Rather, it‚Äôs a simplified approximation of the world Curtis Yarvin, Silicon Valley‚Äôs favourite thinker, wants to usher in. Yarvin, whose ‚Äúdark enlightenment‚Äù ideas have influenced the Trump administration and political kingmakers such as Peter Thiel, believes super-rich elites should have dictatorial powers; universities and the press shouldn‚Äôt hold any sway; and the hoi polloi should suck it all up.

Musk is not a straightforward disciple of Yarvin, but both believe governments should be treated as corporations and share disdain for liberal democracy and ‚Äúwoke‚Äù institutions. Both also have a raze-and-rebuild approach to the world. Indeed, long before Musk launched his Department of Government Efficiency (Doge), Yarvin devised Rage, a plan to ‚Äúretire all government employees‚Äù. Yarvin, by the way, wasn‚Äôt impressed with Doge (he compared it to an orchestra of chimpanzees trying to perform Wagner) because it didn‚Äôt grab enough power.

I bring all this up because, as Musk vies for a larger role on the world stage, it‚Äôs imperative we‚Äôre clear about what he‚Äôs trying to achieve. The billionaire, who spent more than $290m (¬£210m) influencing the US election, is increasingly taking his political meddling worldwide: he inserted himself into Canadian politics earlier this year and helped boost Germany‚Äôs far-right Alternative f√ºr Deutschland (AfD). Musk spent January posting about grooming gangs in the UK and turned his attention back to the country over the weekend, appearing via video at a far-right rally in London. Musk called for a ‚Äúchange of government‚Äù and said: ‚ÄúViolence is coming to you. You either fight back or you die.‚Äù A man who was born in South Africa but emigrated to the US by way of Canada wants Britons to be terrified of foreigners.

So what‚Äôs the end goal here? Is Musk being guided by a Yarvinesque ideology or is this just what happens when the industrial amounts of ketamine the billionaire is reported to have consumed interact with the world‚Äôs largest ego?

While a God complex may be at play, a politics of chaos appears to be Musk‚Äôs short-term goal. It feels increasingly as if the tech mogul is trying to stoke civil unrest and destabilise democracies worldwide so he can accumulate more power. In his new year address, Robert Habeck, Germany‚Äôs vice-chancellor at the time, came to a similar conclusion, calling Musk‚Äôs support for the AfD a ‚Äúlogical and systematic‚Äù play to weaken Europe. ‚ÄúA weak Europe is in the interest of those for whom regulation is an inappropriate limitation of their power,‚Äù Habeck said.

Keir Starmer‚Äôs weaknesses ‚Äì his approval rating is dismal ‚Äì certainly seem to have captured Musk‚Äôs interest. Musk may not have an ideology as developed as Yarvin‚Äôs, but it does feel as if he‚Äôs attempting to become de facto CEO of the world, with deputies around the globe. It‚Äôs not inconceivable that Musk could effect regime change in Britain. And I‚Äôm not sure the government is taking this threat seriously enough. At a time when pensioners are being arrested for waving ‚ÄúPalestine Action‚Äù placards, the response to Musk‚Äôs calls for people to ‚Äúfight back or ‚Ä¶ die‚Äù at a protest where 26 police officers were injured could have been somewhat more forceful. Starmer should impose sanctions on Musk, not just wag his finger at him.

What‚Äôs really at issue here, however, is the system that produced Musk and enabled his meddling. A healthy democracy should have safeguards in place that ensure a handful of super-rich individuals can‚Äôt usurp the political process. Those safeguards were removed from the US in 2010 with the supreme court‚Äôs Citizens United ruling, which reversed century-old campaign finance restrictions and in effect allowed corporations and special interest groups to spend unlimited money on elections. Britain has nowhere near the amount of money sloshing through its politics as the US does, but an analysis last year found dark money is rife: almost ¬£1 in every ¬£10 donated to British parties and politicians came from unknown or dubious sources.

Musk is odious, but he is right that Britain is under threat: if we don‚Äôt fight to conserve democracy, it will die. However, the foreigners we should worry about are not desperate people on small boats, they‚Äôre billionaires with rocket ships.

‚Ä¢ Arwa Mahdawi is a Guardian columnist

title: World Athletics Championships 2025: Kipyegon wins fourth 1500m title, Tinch storms to 110m hurdles gold ‚Äì as it happened
description: Faith Kipyegon won the women‚Äôs 1500m for the fourth time in a row, while Cordell Tinch took the men‚Äôs 110 hurdles
content:
4.12pm BST

The reports are coming in:

Related: USA‚Äôs Cordell Tinch goes from toilet paper factory to 110m hurdles world champion

Related: Australia‚Äôs Jess Hull takes 1500m bronze after brave race against Kenya legend Faith Kipyegon

Related: Time comes for Gout Gout to prove himself against sprinting‚Äôs best emerging talent | Jack Snape

4.04pm BST

‚ÄòThere‚Äôs never been anyone like [Bolt]‚Äô

Related: Oblique Seville backs current sprint crop to get down to 9.6sec but says Bolt will always be best

Updated at 4.04pm BST

3.11pm BST

Kipyegon destroys the field for fourth 1500m world gold

Kenya‚Äôs peerless Faith Kipyegon underlined her status as one of the greatest athletes of all time when she convincingly claimed a fourth 1,500 metres world title on Tuesday to go with her three Olympic golds. Kipyegon delivered a gun-to-tape run that destroyed the field as she came home clear in 3 minutes 52.15 seconds. The world record holder matches Hicham El Guerrouj (1997-2003) by claiming four world 1,500m golds and she will also go for a second world 5,000m title later this week. Fellow Kenyan Dorcus Ewoi ran a personal best 3:54.92 for silver while Jessica Hull won Australia‚Äôs first medal in the event when she just held on for bronze in 3:55.16. Reuters

3.10pm BST

Tinch caps brilliant season with 110m hurdles gold

Cordell Tinch capped a superb second season as a professional by winning 110 metres hurdles gold at the World Athletics Championships in 12.99 seconds on Tuesday. The 25-year-old American, the world leader this year, stormed over the 10 hurdles and held off the fast finishers in the run-in to claim his first global title at his first global championships. Orlando Bennett ran a personal best 13.08 to win silver, while his fellow Jamaican Tyler Mason took the bronze in 13.12, which matched his previous best time. Olympic gold medallist Grant Holloway‚Äôs six-year reign as world champion ended earlier on Tuesday when the American finished sixth in his semi-final. Reuters

3.04pm BST

Otherwise, we‚Äôre done here for today ‚Äì but please do check back for Sean Ingle‚Äôs reports, which‚Äôll be up soon.

Otherwise, join us again tomorrow at 11am BST, for our first look at our 200m runners ‚Äì among them Gout Gout ‚Äì building up to the men‚Äôs 1500m final, tomorrow‚Äôs undoubted highlight featuring Josh Kerr, Jake Wightman, and plenty of others. Peace out.

3.01pm BST

That‚Äôs the end of today‚Äôs competition, but fear not: look what‚Äôs in store for us tomorrow! Tasty!

3.00pm BST

Faith tells BBC she just wants to thanks God. She knew she was capable of defending her title after breaking the world record in Eugene. She wanted to run comfortably and was a bit scared having seen people fall, but only God knows what comes next.

2.58pm BST

Matt Hudson-Smith speaks to BBC, lamenting ‚Äúone of those days‚Äù. Asked if he‚Äôs got a hip issue, he says ‚ÄúI‚Äôm here to run, no excuses‚Äù. He executed to the best of his ability, he goes on, and he‚Äôs so, so disappointed, you can tell. He was expected to make the final at the very least and really to get a medal, but the way he ran in the heats, you could tell that was unlikely, and I fear he‚Äôs some soul searching to come ‚Äì though when he gets home, he‚Äôs a newborn daughter waiting for him.

2.54pm BST

Hamish Kerr of New Zealand wins gold in the high jump with a leap of 2.36m

Sanghyeok Wu of South Korea takes silver and Jan Stefela of Chechia bronze.

Updated at 3.57pm BST

2.52pm BST

Woo tries 2.38 and isn‚Äôt close; Kerr, the Olympic champ, isn‚Äôt either. If the Korean can‚Äôt get over next go, it‚Äôs over.

2.49pm BST

‚Ä¶and Kerr flings himself over! Woo will have to increase the height of the bar if he‚Äôs to steal the gold, so up it goes to 2.38.

Updated at 2.49pm BST

2.47pm BST

The bar goes up to 2.36, Woo to take first go, and he can‚Äôt haul himself over. Can Kerr? He gets the crowd going, breathes, and sets off‚Ä¶

2.45pm BST

Stefela gets up well ‚Ä¶ but the bar comes down and he buries his face in the mat. He didn‚Äôt come for bronze, but that‚Äôs what he‚Äôs got. He gets up, flips, and he‚Äôs happier now, congratulating Kerr and Woo, who‚Äôll now contest the gold.

2.43pm BST

Doroshchuk fails and finishes fourth; check to Chechia and Stefela.

2.42pm BST

‚Ä¶and he‚Äôs over too!

2.42pm BST

Woo gets it going again, smiling all over his face ‚Ä¶ AND HE‚ÄôS OVER! He slaps his own face in delight, and the others have one go at clearing 2.34, or this is over. Here comes Hamish‚Ä¶

2.40pm BST

Doroshchuk and Stefela both miss on their second go; if no one clears any further height, Woo wins on countback from Stefela from Kerr.

2.39pm BST

Related: ‚ÄòI still have homework to do‚Äô: USA‚Äôs 16-year-old 800m star Cooper Lutkenhaus misses world semi-final

2.38pm BST

Now we‚Äôre back to Woo, who gets the crowd and himself going, but again, nowhere near. What can Hamish come up with Up with what can Hamish come? Er, not much, he was much closer first go.

Updated at 2.38pm BST

2.36pm BST

‚Ä¶and he too isn‚Äôt close.

2.35pm BST

Doroshchuk gets nowhere near 2.34, leaping through the bar, and now Stefela will have a shy‚Ä¶

2.35pm BST

Now Kerr, the Olympic champ, also over at that height, goes for 2.34 ‚Ä¶ and gets really close, but catches the bar with his elbow.

2.33pm BST

Righto, time to focus on the men‚Äôs high jump final. Woo has just gone over 2.31 ‚Äì Stefela of Chechia, Kerr of Australia and Doroshchuk of Ukraine are already sorted.

2.31pm BST

Looking at the race again, Tinch didn‚Äôt hit the front until maybe the fifth hurdle, but you knew he‚Äôd power through from well before that. He was ready for this.

2.29pm BST

'‚ÄúI love you Mum!‚Äù Tinch calls into the camera, and rightly so; she reminded him to make the most of his talent when he‚Äôd pretty much quit athletics, and imagine how proud she‚Äôll be now.

2.28pm BST

Muratake exploded out of the blocks, but he couldn‚Äôt control his speed; he was out of it by the third flight. Tinch, on the other hand, was more considered, but by the same stage the race was effectively his. He‚Äôs not the quickest between the barriers, but he was excellent getting over them, and didn‚Äôt he enjoy the moment. Well done, old mate.

2.26pm BST

Cordell Tinch of USA wins the men's 110m hurdles in 12.99

Bennett and Mason, both of Jamaica, take silver and bronze respectively.

Updated at 3.58pm BST

2.25pm BST

Muratake is away brilliantly but hits the first two barriers and Tinch is coming through!

2.25pm BST

They take their marks. There‚Äôll be some serious nerves down there, given how nasty and quick this event is.

2.23pm BST

Our hurdlers are on the track, and this race feels pretty open. Imagine the noise of Muratake of Japan, drawn in lane five, comes through; Mason of Jamaica is also a threat.

2.21pm BST

Ethan Katzberg of Canada wins the hammer

Merlin Hummel of Germany takes silver and Bence Halasz of Hungary bronze.

Updated at 3.58pm BST

2.20pm BST

We‚Äôre five minutes away from the men‚Äôs 110m hurdles final. Cordell Tinch looked pretty good in the semis, and he‚Äôs the favourite.

As it goes, he almost didn‚Äôt become an athlete ‚Äì he went to college on a football scholarship, decided he preferred running, and left it at that. But then he returned home to protect his mental health, and following the pandemic, got a job selling phones, only for his mum and a mate to convince him to move colleges, give track his all, and here we are.

2.14pm BST

2.13pm BST

Faith Kipyegon is something else. There was literally nothing that anyone could do to stop her, however that race went: had someone gone off like Paula Ivan, she‚Äôd have chased them down; in the event, she led from the front, kicked, and devastated the field.

2.11pm BST

Faith Kipyegon of Kenya wins the women's 1500m in 3:52.15, her fourth world title in a row!

It‚Äôs just incredible how much better Kipyegon is than everyone else. Her teammate Ewoi came through for second with Hull, who tied to chase and challenge for gold, taking bronze for Australia.

Updated at 3.59pm BST

2.09pm BST

Kipyegon still leads, a couple of yards between her and Hull now. Those two are clear now, but Faith has gone and this is poetry! It‚Äôs amazing, again, from the greatest of all time!

2.09pm BST

With 600 to go, Kipyegon turns it up gradually, but as they take the bell, expect her to stomp on the gas‚Ä¶

2.08pm BST

We‚Äôre coming up to halfway with Kipyegon leading from Hull from Chepchirchir. Who‚Äôll kick first?

2.07pm BST

Kipyegon leads from Hull of Australia, and the pace isn‚Äôt too quick. I don‚Äôt think we‚Äôre seeing a world record today.

2.06pm BST

The gun goes, and off goes the women‚Äôs 1500m final. Kipyegon goes straight to the front.

2.04pm BST

‚ÄúA thousand wows at how effortless Sydney McLaughlin-Levrone makes the 400m look,‚Äù writes Ben Cooke. ‚ÄúShades of the great Allyson Felix‚Äôs athletic elegance; a sprinting swan gliding towards greatness. Fingers-crossed Tokyo‚Äôs fast track leads to something special in Friday‚Äôs final.‚Äù

I was thinking Flo-Jo and Rudisha but yup, I‚Äôll absolutely allow Felix.

2.03pm BST

Back to Faith, though, is she going to try for a world record? It‚Äôs in her, you‚Äôd think, and she‚Äôs so dominant she can actually justify going for it with a medal at stake ‚Äì what a flex that‚Äôd be.

2.01pm BST

Hudson-Smith lies prostate on the track, James alongside him. This was‚Äôt what he‚Äôd have hoped for, but he didn‚Äôt look in the best shape ‚Äì the speed endurance just wasn‚Äôt there. He was in touch coming off the bend, while Ndori had loads left.

2.00pm BST

There‚Äôs no time to reflect because it‚Äôs time for the women‚Äôs 1500m final.

1.58pm BST

Ndori, also of Botswana powers through as Hudson-Smith tires, and Nkajima of Japan takes second! Richards and Patterson qualify as fastest losers, both form heat two; Hudson-Smith finishes sixth.

Updated at 1.59pm BST

1.57pm BST

Hudson-Smith gets moving immediately, but James, 2012 Olympic champ, flies out of the blocks. Hudsson-Smith is in touch as they come off the curve‚Ä¶.

1.56pm BST

Hudson-Smith really tied up in the heat, having run a decent race prior to the final 100. He‚Äôll know how he feels now, but in lane two, having qualified as a fastest loser, he‚Äôs got a lot of work to do chasing the men in front. McRae of USA is probably the favourite; he goes in six.

1.54pm BST

Charlie Dobson, by the way, was seventh; he and Reardon stick about to see how Hudson-Smith gets on in what is probably the weakest of the semis.

1.53pm BST

There‚Äôs something happening in Botswana athletics. Kebinatshipi wasn‚Äôt expected to do what he did here ‚Äì he‚Äôs only 21 ‚Äì but he led at the top of the home straight and just kept going. Amazing performance, and I can‚Äôt wait to see what he‚Äôs got for us in the final.

1.52pm BST

Goodness me, Kebinatshipi wins in 43.61! That‚Äôs the fastest time in the world this year and looks chill at the end! He‚Äôs got faster in him I reckon, and McDonald of Jamaica is second; Richards of T&T is third, with, Patterson a distant fourth.

1.50pm BST

Patterson is away pretty well and he starts putting it in around the bend, but Kebinatshipi leads by miles! Patterson is getting run out of this!

1.48pm BST

Doroshchuk of Ukraine and Harrison of USA also get over 2.28 in the men‚Äôs high jump, the competition intensifying. But it‚Äôs now time for the second men‚Äôs 400m semi, Jacory Patterson the favourite after a fine run in his heat; Charlie Dobson goes for GB.

1.46pm BST

Nene is a lovely mover, so smooth and compact in style. He looks ready for this.

1.45pm BST

Eppie of Botswana is second; Reardon finishes eighth.

Updated at 1.45pm BST

1.44pm BST

As the stagger unwinds, Nene looks over his shoulder ‚Äì he‚Äôs miles clear.

1.44pm BST

Away they go, Nene away sharply and looking so relaxed.

1.43pm BST

Down go our 400m men again‚Ä¶

1.42pm BST

Oooh, and then Kerr, the Olympic champ, nails it first go.

1.41pm BST

This time they get away only to be called back, for no obvious reason. Up goes the tension, another green card is shown, then it‚Äôs back down ‚Ä¶ but Woo wants to take a jump first and he fails at 2.28.

1.38pm BST

Back to the men‚Äôs 400, Christopher Bailey of USA is another who might challenge, but Nene is favourite; again, though, they‚Äôre stood up and a green card brandished.

1.35pm BST

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs definitely a confidence builder,‚Äù Sydney tells BBC. ‚ÄúJust gotta go out in the final and execute.‚Äù

Having watched the semis, a race I thought might be one of the best of the meet, now looks like her against the clock.

1.33pm BST

Right, the men will be with us shortly. Zakithi Nene of South Africa, the fastest in the world this year, goes in heat one, likewise GB‚Äôs Sam Reardon; Matt Hudson-Smith is in three.

1.31pm BST

Oh, and McLaughlin-Levrone also broke ‚Äì annihilated really ‚Äì Sanya Richards-Ross‚Äô US record of 48.70, and she‚Äôs going to monster it again in the final, I‚Äôm certain. By the look of her, she‚Äôs barely trying, and is Marita Koch‚Äôs record of 47.60, set in 1985, under threat? I really, really hope so.

1.28pm BST

McLaughlin-Levrone wins in 48.29, the fastest time in the world this year and joint-fastest ever, with Anning of GB taking second, great performance. Pryce of Jamaica is third; she and Jaeger qualify for the final as fastest losers, but seriously, Sydney is just amazing. I can‚Äôt see how anyone can beat her, at anything.

1.26pm BST

McLaughlin-Levrone leads, obviously, and she‚Äôs miles clear, floating over the track.

1.25pm BST

It‚Äôs Sydney time. I love her commitment to testing herself, and i love that Femke Bol, her big hurdles rival, was gutted they‚Äôd not be competing against each other.

1.23pm BST

Katzberg then lets go a monster but at an angle; will it stay within the sector? Just, and he‚Äôs back into the lead at 84.70, a lifetime best and championship record. Decent response to losing the lead, all things considered.

1.22pm BST

Hummel of Germany hurls the hammer 82.77 and he takes the lead, leading Katzberg of Canada, the world and Olympic champ, and Halasz of Hungary.

1.21pm BST

Naser wins in 49.47, looking awesome. Whittaker of USA and Klaver of the Netherlands, both of whom woud‚Äôve hoped for better, are third and fourth, the former now sat with Jaeger waiting to see if their ties are enough to qualify for the final as fastest losers.

1.18pm BST

It‚Äôs a steady start, then Naser starts eating ground, and she‚Äôs well ahead around the top bend, the rest racing for second. Gomez of Puerto Rico is alone in second.

1.17pm BST

They get down, but are then stood up again for reasons unclear; a green card is produced, and we‚Äôre back to it.

Updated at 1.17pm BST

1.16pm BST

Eyes down for heat two of the women‚Äôs 400 semis, Ohuruogu the GB representation. Naser looked amazing in the heats, but things are starting to get real now‚Ä¶

1.13pm BST

In the men‚Äôs high jump, Woo of South Korea leads with 2.24; various of the rest are over 2.20.

Updated at 1.20pm BST

1.12pm BST

Gosh, Paulino looks calm, but her efforts to affect control almost cost her. That is not how she wanted things to go, but she‚Äôs through, but five one-hundredths of a second.

1.10pm BST

‚Ä¶or is she? She slows up and Bukowiecka goes by, and Jaeger is catching as she walks over the line! She makes it, just, but that was almost a disaster.

1.09pm BST

As the stagger unwinds, Paulino leads and she‚Äôs going to win easily‚Ä¶

Updated at 1.12pm BST

1.09pm BST

Off they go, Paulino starting calmly, then putting it in around the top bend.

1.07pm BST

Our heat one runners are out on the track, Paulino, the world and Olympic champ, in lane six.

1.06pm BST

Also in the 400m semis is Amber Anning, who came fifth in the Olympic final but won the world indoors earlier this year. It feels impossible for anyone other than the big three to win a medal, but you never know.

1.02pm BST

It‚Äôs fast and furious now. The men‚Äôs hammer final is just getting going, while the women‚Äôs 400m semis are coming up in six minutes; I can‚Äôt wait to see how the big three of Paulino, Naser and McLaughlin-Levrone pull up.

12.59pm BST

Oooh, Mason‚Äôs winning time of 13.12, the quickest of the round, was a PB. Biggup!

12.58pm BST

Holloway‚Äôs dicky knee just didn‚Äôt give him the stability he needed to time his jumps. He ended up sixth; the champ is out.

12.57pm BST

Mason wins, Muratake takes second, just, with third and fourth ‚Äì Tharp of USA and Kwaou-Mathey of France taking both fastest-loser spots.

12.56pm BST

Muratake gets away well but Holloway is nowhere and Mason of Jamaica is going to win!

12.55pm BST

Right, what does Grant Holloway have for us? We‚Äôll soon find out, but the crowd are more interested in Rachid Muratake; can he bring it home for Japan?

12.52pm BST

It‚Äôs amazing really, Tinch was slow out of the blocks and yet well in front by the first obstacle. Joseph came back at him well, though, and Colin reckons if he‚Äôs still in the final at 50m, he‚Äôs a serious danger.

12.50pm BST

Tinch takes it in 13.16, with Joseph of Switzerland second; Prince and Simonelli are third and fourth, and I think that‚Äôll be the end of Beard. Yup, he and Namoto are gawn.

Updated at 12.58pm BST

12.49pm BST

Tinch staggers at the gun but he recovers and he‚Äôs going to win‚Ä¶

12.48pm BST

Semi two is good to go, Cordell Tinch in lane three.

12.48pm BST

What a race this was, in the 1993 worlds.

12.44pm BST

‚Ä¶but he fades as Bennett of Jamaica powers to victory in 13.27, with Llopis of Spain second. I‚Äôm not sure Beard even got third ‚Ä¶ and the roar tells us he didn‚Äôt, Nomoto of Japan edging him. He‚Äôs in big trouble.

12.43pm BST

Dylan Beard, also of USA, looks the favourite here and he leads at halfway‚Ä¶

12.41pm BST

The final of the men‚Äôs high jump is just starting while, on the track, we‚Äôve the three heats of the men‚Äôs 110m hurdles. Grant Holloway didn‚Äôt enjoy his heat performance and earlier, Colin Jackson explained that his timing is off, legs not working in concert and the trail coming over too slowly. We‚Äôll see how he‚Äôs set shortly, likewise Cordell Tinch, who goes in heat two and looked terrific yesterday.

12.38pm BST

I can‚Äôt wait for this: tomorrow, Gout Gout makes his major tournament debut. A PB and/or a final spot would be a pretty good return, as he continues exploring the extent of his talent.

12.34pm BST

Heat seven is away and Brazier of USA, who won in Doha in 2019 but has been struggling with injury, looks pretty good. He wins, from Moula of Algeria, who came from a long way back, with Bloudek of Croatia taking third; Kebenei of Kenya qualifies too, as a fastest loser, likewise the aforementioned Meziane and Crestan.

12.28pm BST

Burgin tells BBC that he‚Äôs happy with his race. He ran it ‚Äúnice and safely‚Äù to finish in the automatic spot, but the heats are always stressful. He knew he needed to run 1:44 ‚Äìsorry, your 1:44s to qualify ‚Äì and did, ‚Äútextbook, really‚Äù. He knows he‚Äôs capable of getting a medal having raced these lads all year, and the gap between warming up and arriving at the track is taking a bit of getting used to, but you can tell he‚Äôs feeling great.

12.25pm BST

Also going on:

Related: Surrey v Nottinghamshire, Sussex v Yorkshire, and more: county cricket, day two ‚Äì live

12.25pm BST

Related: Golden George Beamish delivers kick for New Zealand athletics at world championships | Jack Snape

12.24pm BST

Burgin wins from Masalela in 1:44.73, the fastest time so far, with Anderson of Jamaica third. Meziane of France and Crestan of Belgium have a decent chance of going through too, as fastest losers.

Updated at 12.34pm BST

12.22pm BST

Burgin sits second at the bell, Masalela of Botswana leading. The pace is pretty quick, but the front two look strong.

12.21pm BST

Heat six of the men‚Äôs 800 features Max Burgin, seventh-fastest in the world this year and finally fully fit. He‚Äôll fancy himself for a medal here, having had a really good season, but first things first.

12.19pm BST

I should say, I enjoyed BBC‚Äôs field commentator ‚Äì apologies, I missed them telling us who it is ‚Äì saying for the coaches, it‚Äôs like playing a video game and moving your hands in the direction you hope your character goes in. I spent chunks of my childhood doing that playing Mario on the NES.

12.17pm BST

This is a swift one, Gouned of Algeria stretching it out with violence. But he ties up in the last 50m, Wanyonyi taking it from English of Ireland and Pernici of Italy.

12.15pm BST

But stop everything: Steve Cram has just delivered a delicious piece of exhibition pluralisation, talking about ‚Äúyour 1.45s‚Äù to describe the kind of time it‚Äôll take to qualify as a fastest loser.

12.13pm BST

Heat five of the men‚Äôs 800m heat features Emmanuel Wanyonyi, the fastest in the world this year, while Peyton Craig, the 20-year-old Aussie, is also worth watching out for.

12.07pm BST

Out of nowhere, Cian McPhillips of Ireland powers down the home straight to win easily; he looked great there. Hoppel is second, with Taylor of Jamaica third. Bol of Australia has to wait.

Updated at 12.13pm BST

12.04pm BST

Bryce Hoppel of USA, sixth fastest in the world this year, is the favourite for heat four; his PB of 1:41.67 is not to be messed with.

12.02pm BST

Pattison says he hadn‚Äôt planned to control the race, but he got to the front and thought he‚Äôd slow it down, trusting his kick. He made sure not to get boxed, adding that he felt better than in a long time warming up ‚Äì he‚Äôs been injured ‚Äì but has a medal to defend and a job to do. On Lutkenhaus, he says ‚ÄúI saw 2008 on the start list and I was almost sick,‚Äù adding that if he‚Äôd run in this kind of race at 16, he‚Äôd have been 100m off the back. He sounds really confident.

11.57am BST

Lutkenhaus has left himself too much to do, too reliant on a kick he didn‚Äôt quite time. Wyderka of Poland wins, from Pattison, from Tual of France.

Updated at 12.05pm BST

11.57am BST

Lutkenhaus is really wide and still at the back as they move round the bend into the home straight; Pattison is second.

Updated at 12.00pm BST

11.56am BST

Heat three of the men‚Äôs 800 features Cooper Lutkenhaus, a 16-year-old prodigy from Texas, as well as Ben Pattison of GB, who won a surprise bronze in Budapest.

11.53am BST

It‚Äôs Rojas time! Here she comes ‚Ä¶ and lands at 14.49m, easily exceeding the automatic qualifying mark of 14.35. Welcome back, old mate.

Updated at 12.22pm BST

11.51am BST

So Attaoui of Spain wins, from Loti of Kenya, with Arop joining them in the next round. He has an interesting story, by the way, escaping Sudan during the civil war for Egypt, before moving to Canada, where he excelled at basketball ‚Äì then his high school coach suggested he focus on track, and here he is.

11.49am BST

Crorken gets a shift on in the last 100m but he won‚Äôt quire get there; meantime, Attaoui surges to the front and Arop, suddenly in third, is under pressure from Chapple ‚Ä¶ but he hangs in there to seal the final semi-final spot. Just as well, because he‚Äôd not have been a fastest loser.

11.47am BST

Arop, the defending champ and Olympic silver medallist, leads at the bell, Kelvin Lotai of Kenya alongside.

11.46am BST

The second heat is away and, after a swift start they settle, Arop at the front.

11.45am BST

In comms, they note that on the circuit, most races have pacemakers, and running without them is a leveller because it offers those not capable of the fastest times a chance to compete. Exhibit A:

11.41am BST

Tiarnan Crorken of GB goes in heat two. He only hit the qualifying standard just in time; the in-form runners are Marco Arop of Canada and Mohamed Attaoui of Spain.

11.39am BST

Sedjati looks strong down the home straight and he eases up on the line to finish second; Barroso of Spain wins, with Haingura of Botswana fourth. Chuot of Qatar left himself too much to do, and he‚Äôll have regrets ‚Äì he‚Äôs not totally spent, and had the race gone another 5-10m, he‚Äôd have been asking a serious question of those in front. Instead, he has to wait.

Updated at 11.42am BST

11.36am BST

And off they go‚Ä¶

11.36am BST

We‚Äôre almost ready to start with heat one of seven in the men‚Äôs 800m. The first three in each heat go through to the semis, along with the three fastest losers. Djamel Sedjati of Algeria, the Olympic silver medallist, is the class of this field.

11.32am BST

Hudson-Smith, we learn, tightened up on the bus to the stadium, hence his relatively poor run in the heat. Presumably he‚Äôll have taken steps to recuperate and avoid the same problem; hopefully for him, two days was enough to get things sorted.

11.29am BST

Today, though, we‚Äôll have to make do with the final of the men‚Äôs high jump, which looks likely to feature a three-way battle for gold between Sangyhyeok Woo of South Korea, Hamish Kerr of New Zealand and Oleh Doroshchuk of Ukraine.

On the women‚Äôs side, we‚Äôve triple jump qualifying, which means a chance to enjoy Yulimar Rojas, who missed the Paris Olympics with a ruptured Achilles but won gold in Tokyo ‚Äì and in the last four editions of this competition. She‚Äôs not competed since getting hurt, so we‚Äôve not a clue how she might go, but no one loves the big occasion more.

Updated at 11.42am BST

11.23am BST

Tomorrow is the men‚Äôs long jump final. I‚Äôm not on then, so I‚Äôm afraid I‚Äôm going to have to post this today, from the 1991 edition of this meet: the greatest field event competition of all time.

11.12am BST

11.10am BST

Mondo isn‚Äôt just great at pole vaulting ‚Äì he‚Äôs also a neologian, saying that after breaking the world record again, he was ‚Äúsuper-overwhelmed‚Äù. File above ‚Äúover-exaggerate‚Äù.

11.08am BST

Now it‚Äôs on to Faith, perhaps the greatest all-round athlete on the planet ‚Äì she‚Äôs hoping to do the 1500m and 5000m double here, and her own world record in the former, set earlier this year, is also under threat tonight. The time to aim for is 3:48.68.

Meantime, Jess Ennis, in the studio, reckons that if you‚Äôre driven, you have mum strength after giving birth because everything you do you‚Äôre doing for your kid. Kipyegon has a daughter, Alyn ‚Äì born in 2018 ‚Äì with her husband, Timothy Kitum, who won bronze in the 800m at the London Olympics.

11.04am BST

Of course BBC open their broadcast with talk of Mondo. Has anyone ever been better at anything than he is at pole vault? At least he‚Äôs not devilishly handsome; that‚Äôd be really unfair if that were also so.

Updated at 11.47am BST

11.03am BST

Order of events

10.30am BST

Preamble

„Åì„Çì„Å´„Å°„ÅØ ‚Äì kon‚Äônichiwa ‚Äì and welcome to the World Athletics Championships ‚Äì night four!

And, of course, it‚Äôs another nicky banger. Matt Hudson-Smith, Olympic 400m silver medallist, found it tough in qualifying, a leggy last 150m leaving him reliant on a fastest loser‚Äôs semi-final spot. But he made it, the question now what he‚Äôs got left ‚Äì but he‚Äôs had a little more luck: he runs in heat three, with Jacory Patterson, so impressive on Sunday night, in heat two and Zakithi Nene, fastest in the world this year, in one.

The women‚Äôs event looks just as exciting, our three favourites kept apart. In heat one goes Marieldy Paulino, the Olympic champ, while in two, we‚Äôve Salwa Eid Naser, this year‚Äôs fastest, and in three, Sydney McLaughlin-Levrone, the Olympic gold medallist in the 400m hurdles having switched to flat in search of a new event to dominate. It‚Äôs going to be hot.

Those, though, are our appetisers. The centrepiece of the evening could well be the men‚Äôs 110m hurdles, in which Rachid Muratake, the home favourite, is chasing gold. He‚Äôll do well to get by USA‚Äôs Grant Holloway and Cordell Tinch, but he‚Äôs got a chance.

Our other track final comes in the women‚Äôs 1500m with the frankly wondrous Faith Kipyegon, undefeated over the distance in more than four years, looking to make (yet more) history. Should she win, the three-time Olympic and three-time world champion will draw level with Hicham El Guerrouj, who won this race at this meet on four occasions, and at 31, it‚Äôs incumbent upon us to savour her while we still can.

Or, in other words, Mondo needs to budge up, because there are others planning to take out a des res inside our heads.

Action starts: 7.35pm local, 11.35am BST

title: Google‚Äôs huge new Essex datacentre to emit 570,000 tonnes of CO2 a year
description:
Exclusive: Planning documents show impact of Thurrock ‚Äòhyperscale‚Äô unit as UK attempts to ramp up AI capacity

  • Business live ‚Äì latest updates

  • UK and US line up deals to build modular nuclear reactors in Britain
content:
A new Google datacentre in Essex is expected to emit more than half a million tonnes of carbon dioxide a year, equivalent to about 500 short-haul flights a week, planning documents show.

Spread across 52 hectares (128 acres), the Thurrock ‚Äúhyperscale datacentre‚Äù will be part of a wave of mammoth computer and AI power houses if it secures planning consent.

The plans were submitted by a subsidiary of Google‚Äôs parent company, Alphabet, and the carbon impact emerged before a concerted push by Donald Trump‚Äôs White House and Downing Street to ramp up AI capacity in Britain. Multibillion-dollar investment deals with some of Silicon Valley‚Äôs biggest tech companies are expected to be announced during the US president‚Äôs state visit to the UK, which starts on Tuesday.

Related: How Google dodged a major breakup ‚Äì and why OpenAI is to thank for it

Keir Starmer‚Äôs government has forecast a 13-fold rise in the amount of computer processing power AI will use by 2035 and is scrambling to supply the datacentres to meet that demand in the hope the technology will boost Britain‚Äôs insipid economic productivity. Deals involving Nvidia, the world‚Äôs largest AI chip maker, and OpenAI, the company behind the ChatGPT AI assistant, are anticipated.

But campaigners have said a wave of massive new computer warehouses will crank up Britain‚Äôs greenhouse gas emissions and put pressure on finite power and water resources.

If allowed, the Thurrock complex will include up to four datacentres on ‚Äúgrey belt‚Äù land part-occupied by a former speedway and stock car track. It ‚Äúwill lead to a net increase in GHG [greenhouse gas] emissions of 568,727 tonnes CO‚ÇÇ–µ [carbon dioxide equivalent] per year during the operational phase‚Äù, planning documents examined by the Guardian show.

That amounts to about 500 flights from Heathrow to M√°laga every week, according to the UN‚Äôs International Civil Aviation Organization‚Äôs carbon calculator. Google‚Äôs planning application stresses this remains a ‚Äúminor adverse and not significant impact when compared to the UK carbon budgets‚Äù, but campaigners disagree.

‚ÄúGoogle‚Äôs planned facility in Essex will produce carbon emissions several times higher than those of an international airport,‚Äù said a spokesperson for Foxglove, a campaign group for fairer technology. ‚ÄúBut this is just one of many ‚Äòhyperscale‚Äô datacentres that US big tech wants to impose on the UK ‚Äì in pursuit of their own profits and regardless of the cost to our environment.

‚ÄúStarmer‚Äôs government needs to stop bowing to the Trump-big tech agenda and start standing up for the interests of the UK public ‚Äì otherwise we will all be paying for the tech giants‚Äô datacentres, whether in terms of soaring energy bills, dwindling water supplies or a heating planet.‚Äù

Datacentres now consume about 2.5% of the UK‚Äôs electricity, and demand on the grid is expected to increase fourfold by 2030, according to the House of Commons library.

The British government does not believe datacentres will have a significant impact on the UK‚Äôs carbon budget because of its ambitious targets for electricity grid decarbonisation. Rather it is worried that without massive investment in new datacentres, the UK will fall behind international rivals, including France, resulting in a ‚Äúcompute gap‚Äù that ‚Äúrisks undermining national security, economic growth, and the UK‚Äôs ambition to lead in AI‚Äù, according to a July research paper from the Department for Science, Innovation and Technology.

Other important datacentre projects include a ¬£10bn scheme on the site of a former coal-fired power station near Blyth in Northumberland that was granted planning permission in March. It is poised to be at the heart of a UK-US deal involving Nvidia and OpenAI. It was also reported at the weekend that Google is in early-stage talks about building a mammoth datacentre on Teesside.

Bain & Company, a global business consultancy, said on Monday that AI and datacentres could account for 2% of global emissions and 17% of industrial emissions by 2035, with the impact highest in countries where fossil fuels still dominate power generation.

Google declined to comment on its planning application for the Thurrock site. On Teesside, it said: ‚ÄúWe do not comment on rumours or speculation.‚Äù

title: Argos was a bad buy ‚Äì but Sainsbury‚Äôs doesn‚Äôt need to sell at a silly price | Nils Pratley
description:
Talks to sell the retailer to China‚Äôs JD.com are over, but they highlight that a sale on respectable terms should be possible

  • Sainsbury‚Äôs talks to sell Argos to Chinese retailer JD.com collapse
content:
The thinking behind Sainsbury‚Äôs ¬£1bn-plus purchase of Argos back in 2016 wasn‚Äôt entirely other-worldly. The big idea was that, by putting Argos general merchandise shops within Sainsbury‚Äôs supermarkets, both chains would benefit via a customer crossover effect. But the problem was also screamingly obvious: why volunteer to step in front of Amazon‚Äôs non-food steamroller?

Simon Roberts became chief executive of Sainsbury‚Äôs in 2020, replacing Mike Coupe, the architect of the Argos deal, and immediately indicated where he stood. His ‚Äúfood first‚Äù strategy wasn‚Äôt quite a declaration that he viewed Argos as inessential to the day job of competing with Tesco et al, but it wasn‚Äôt far off.

Thus nobody was surprised by Sainsbury‚Äôs confirmation on Saturday that it was considering an approach for Argos from JD.com, the enormous Chinese retailer. The identity of the would-be buyer was logical ‚Äì JD.com publicly flirted with the idea of bidding for electrical chain Curry‚Äôs last year and is still thought to be keen on a splashy entry into the UK.

Related: Sainsbury‚Äôs talks to sell Argos to Chinese retailer JD.com collapse

Sunday, however, brought news that the talks were off already because, said Sainsbury‚Äôs, JD.com would only engage on ‚Äúmaterially revised terms and commitments‚Äù. In negotiation-speak, that‚Äôs like calling the other side a bunch of time-wasters. The talks look properly dead. Everybody knows Argos isn‚Äôt worth what it was in 2016, but it‚Äôs still a substantial business.

There is still a possible upside to the messy weekend saga for those Sainsbury‚Äôs investors who view Argos as unwanted baggage. The mere fact of talks suggests Argos has not become so enmeshed in Sainsbury‚Äôs infrastructure that the business could never be separated and sold.

Of the 664 Argos shops, 461 are within a Sainsbury‚Äôs store, so a divorce would still be tricky. But more and more of Argos‚Äôs trade is going online, so perhaps there is still somebody out there who would want the 200-odd rump stand-alone shops, allowing Sainsbury‚Äôs to take back its store space to put to better use.

Sainsbury‚Äôs doesn‚Äôt reveal Argos‚Äôs profits, but the detail-free charts it occasionally publishes suggest margins are slim (certainly slimmer than in the supermarkets) and have been getting slimmer in recent years. On the other hand, turnover at Argos is almost ¬£5bn and digitalisation has happened, so perhaps there is still an appeal for somebody.

For Roberts, Argos is best viewed as a low-level headache. Its presence is annoying for shareholders who would prefer a pure grocery-only story, especially now Sainsbury‚Äôs has sold most of its bank. But the core supermarket business isn‚Äôt obviously being distracted ‚Äì and the weekend update confirmed this year‚Äôs expectations on operating profit and cashflow, which helped the share price. The worry is more the medium-term one that, one day, the demand on Argos to stand on its own feet internally will become impossible to maintain.

It would have been better if Argos had never been bought in the first place because the competitive pressure in non-food is relentless. But it is still fair to turn down offers at silly prices. Roberts has a couple of years to find an alternative ‚Äì either a self-help fix of Argos or a sale on respectable terms. The task is not easy, but nor should it be impossible.

title: Derek Purnell obituary
description: Dancer and later chief executive of Birmingham Royal Ballet who took leading roles at the Wallace Collection and then Strawberry Hill House in London
content:
Derek Purnell, who has died aged 71 of a brain tumour, had a career focused on the arts and heritage encompassing both performance and administration. He had a true sense of purpose and the ability to inspire his colleagues, and always took an interest in their work.

In 1991 he took up the position of chief executive of Birmingham Royal Ballet (BRB), working alongside Peter Wright, the artistic director, and from 1995 with David Bintley. In a tribute, Bintley noted that the decade he worked alongside Purnell at the BRB was ‚Äúthe happiest and most fulfilling of my professional life‚Äù. Having danced with Sadler‚Äôs Wells Royal Ballet, the touring wing of the Royal Ballet, for a decade from 1973, and having become a dancers‚Äô union representative, when Purnell retired from performing he trained in arts administration at City, University of London.

He then returned to Sadler‚Äôs Wells Royal Ballet, where he managed the company‚Äôs 1988 tour to Asia, and was given the task of organising the relocation of the company to Birmingham to make its home at the Hippodrome. Knowing the working conditions dancers aspired to having danced at theatres with less-than-ideal backstage facilities, he ensured appropriate studios and custom-built facilities were provided there.

He became a valued ambassador for Birmingham as a place to work, reassuring the dancers and staff who would be leaving London. In 1990 the move was complete, and the company became Birmingham Royal Ballet. Purnell also played a leading role in securing BRB‚Äôs independence from the Royal Opera House.

In 2005 he moved from Birmingham to a small village in Norfolk, and began a career as a freelance consultant. He helped to promote the arts in the county and worked with Norfolk Dance. During this period he suffered with and recovered from from throat cancer.

When the opportunity to join the Wallace Collection as director of public engagement arose in 2014, he moved to London. At this museum housing fine art in Manchester Square, off Oxford Street, he championed collaborations between art, music and dance and encouraged the development of outreach programmes.

Three years later he became chief operations officer. He missed being involved with events, so in July 2020 he became director of Strawberry Hill House and Gardens, Twickenham. Strawberry Hill, Horrace Walpole‚Äôs 18th-century gothic house had been lovingly restored in the decade from 2004 and Purnell knew he had to balance preserving the building and keeping it alive.

He enjoyed being involved in making new acquisitions and loans; a portrait of Catherine de Medici, whom Walpole admired, was added to the gallery, and a fishtub from Walpole‚Äôs collection ‚Äì in which his cat was said to have drowned, inspiring Thomas Gray‚Äôs Ode on the Death of a Favourite Cat Drowned in a Tub of Gold Fishes ‚Äì was also displayed.

Purnell supported a range of exhibitions both in the house and online, including one on gothic toy theatres, and community activities in the garden.

Born and brought up in Bristol, Derek claimed that the port city aroused his curiosity about history. He was the younger of two sons of Betty (nee Cornish), an office worker, and John Purnell, who worked for Rolls-Royce. Derek was educated at Monks Park comprehensive, where he enjoyed the benefit of inspiring teachers of English and art; he also studied ballet, taking classes with Bettie Vowles.

At 16 he was accepted into the Royal Ballet upper school, from where he graduated to Sadler‚Äôs Wells Royal Ballet in 1973. He was a versatile performer whose height was an advantage. At one performance he would mime older characters including the Duke of Courland in Giselle or the Russian Merchant in L√©onide Massine‚Äôs La Boutique Fantasque, at the next he revealed his technical skills in the pas de six from Les Rendezvous, the Gypsy Girl‚Äôs Lover in The Two Pigeons, Lysander in The Dream and even a Tomato in Pas de L√©gumes ‚Äì all ballets by Frederick Ashton.

Purnell was also noted for dancing choreography by George Balanchine. While a leading dancer in the corps de ballet, he was chosen for the male lead, partnering Vyvyan Lorrayne, in Concerto Barocco, of which the Times critic wrote: ‚ÄúDerek Purnell in the slow movement supports her with a wholly admirable reticence, almost achieving the illusion that it is Bach‚Äôs music rather than his arms causing her to soar above the stage.‚Äù

In 1974 he married Elizabeth Cunliffe, a dancer and Benesh movement notator, with whom he had a daughter, Louise. That marriage was dissolved, and in 1982 he married Aileen Morrison, a viola player who worked with many orchestras. They met when she was playing with the Sadler‚Äôs Wells Ballet orchestra. Their daughter Kirsty now teaches on several dance outreach programmes.

Purnell retained his love of dance, serving as a governor of the Royal Ballet, and was active on several committees, including serving as vice-chair of the board of trustees of the Royal Academy of Dance. In 2024 Purnell was on the verge of taking up the position of executive director of the Frederick Ashton Foundation.

He is survived by Aileen and his two daughters.

‚Ä¢ Derek James Purnell, dancer and arts administrator, born 5 April 1954; died 2 August 2025

title: Giant: Rock Hudson and James Dean‚Äôs epic family drama that lives up to its name
description: Hudson, Dean and Elizabeth Taylor make a thrilling trio in this decades-spanning saga set on a scorching Texan ranch
content:
‚ÄúI think Rock Hudson worked best with a big background,‚Äù says film historian Steve Hayes in a biography of the Hollywood heart-throb, ‚Äúin a big melodrama against a big landscape‚Äù. It doesn‚Äôt get much bigger than George Stevens‚Äô three-and-a-half-hour epic Giant, starring the towering Hudson ‚Äì who stood 6ft 5in at the height of his fame.

Adapted from Edna Ferber‚Äôs 1952 bestseller of the same name, Giant is a film of great conscience and scale, tracing multiple decades of a southern family reckoning with social and political tailwinds on their ranch. Often described as the national movie of Texas, Giant actually begins further east in the state of Maryland where Jordan ‚ÄúBick‚Äù Benedict Jr (Hudson) has journeyed to buy a horse fit for his 595,000 acres of land. There he meets and quickly marries debutante Leslie Lynnton, played by a young Elizabeth Taylor.

Without second thought, the well-mannered, equestrian flower of the east ‚Äì a clear case of typecasting for Taylor, who earlier won hearts as a teenage horse-whisperer in National Velvet ‚Äì leaves it all behind for a life saddled at Bick‚Äôs side on his grand cattle ranch under the flaming Texan sun.

‚ÄúHot? It was about 120 degrees in the shade!‚Äù Taylor said of the storied summer shoot, which took a horrific turn when co-star Mercedes McCambridge was seriously scarred after make-up melted into her skin, burning her neck. Ironically, it‚Äôs McCambridge‚Äôs Luz, Bick Benedict‚Äôs spinster sister, that is most at home in these scorching conditions. Early in the film, Luz hosts an outdoor barbecue on a sweltering day to welcome her new sister-in-law to the community, which includes the avoidant ranch-hand Jett Rink ‚Äì played by Giant‚Äôs true star James Dean. Luz‚Äôs friendly hazing sees Leslie faint before the entire town. As an easterner, her blood is ‚Äútoo thin‚Äù for Texas.

Yet from the moment of her arrival, Leslie‚Äôs presence brings about an important shift in the town. Unlike her husband, she shows basic respect for Mexican workers on the ranch ‚Äì her progressive instincts no doubt a reflection of the political upbringing she received as an upper-class girl in the more progressive Maryland.

In the many years it spans, Giant endeavours to form a political picture of the south, from early debates between the newlyweds over the status of Texas as a ‚Äústolen state‚Äù to the penultimate scene where Bick brawls with a small-business owner refusing service to a Mexican family. The great accomplishment of the story is that it is one where a man of great stature admits that he was wrong.

The other primary thread in Giant is the making of another man ‚Äì Jett ‚Äì into an emperor. With his humble beginnings as a worker on Bick‚Äôs station, Jett comes into a great fortune when he discovers the small share of the ranch bequeathed to him by the late Luz sits above an oil well. His realisation is a moment of spectacular eruption: the well ejaculates suddenly, spraying his humble plot with glorious black grease. Jett is going to be a very wealthy man ‚Äì the consequences of which become clear as the years tick by and characters age.

Early in the casting process Stevens made the unusual decision to hire actors in their 20s as his three leads, each of which would go on to play their characters in middle age during Giant‚Äôs second act. In his transformation, Hudson, who was 28 at the time, wore a 50-pound belt as padding around his waist. He and the 23-year-old Taylor wore substantial make-up to create the illusion ‚Äì and yet it was Dean, as a greying oil tycoon, that transformed most convincingly. The actor refused the same cosmetics as his co-stars, arguing that ‚Äúa man of 45 shows his age in thoughts and actions, not in wrinkles‚Äù. Dean‚Äôs performance ‚Äì informed by his time in Texas with real cowboys ‚Äì is a masterclass in swagger, down to Jett‚Äôs speech pattern and the way he wears his big hat.

Related: Hooper: the film that turned the stuntman into a movie star

As a reliquary of three of Hollywood‚Äôs brightest stars, Giant also imagines an alternate history where Hudson, Taylor and Dean were allowed to age alongside one another. Hudson died of Aids in the mid-80s, becoming one of the first beloved public figures associated with the disease. Fans across the world were shocked to find their hero reduced to a sick old man, sadly more sick than he was old. Needless to say, James Dean never aged beyond Giant. He famously crashed his race car in California shortly after filming was complete. Taylor was the only one who survived well into the 21st century in a life defined by both richesse and heartbreak, alternatingly assailed and adored by the public eye until her death, aged 79.

Witnessing the trio in Giant now feels like summoning ghosts. When 200 minutes have elapsed and the film is finally over, it‚Äôs almost a disappointment. Thanks to the cavalcade of great heroes that descended on Marfa, Texas, back in 1955, the night sky of the Lone Star state never looked so bright.

title: AFL finals: where the Collingwood v Brisbane preliminary final will be won and lost | Martin Pegan
description: The Magpies‚Äô high-performing veterans are likely to hit the ground fresh as the Lions aim to become the first side to reach three straight grand finals since Hawthorn
content:
The time is now for Collingwood as they again cross paths with Brisbane at the pointy end of the season, just two years after the powerhouse clubs played out an all-time classic grand final. The past two AFL premiers meet a week earlier this time with a spot in the 2025 decider on the line.

The Magpies are all in on a premiership this year as they back a cast of high-performing veterans who have helped lift them to preliminary final week in three of their four seasons under coach Craig McRae. The Pies built up a strong record against the Lions since breaking their hearts to clinch the 2023 flag with three more victories, including a comprehensive 52-point win in round six this year. Brisbane finally turned the tables on Collingwood when they pulled away to a 27-point triumph during the run home to make a pre-finals statement at the MCG.

Related: AFL finals: where the Geelong v Hawthorn preliminary final will be won and lost | Martin Pegan

The Lions are back on familiar ground while playing in a seventh consecutive finals series with this their fifth preliminary final during that stretch. The first two trips to the penultimate week ended in defeat but the battle-hardened Brisbane are now aiming to become the first side to reach three straight grand finals since Hawthorn completed their premiership three-peat a decade ago.

Where the game will be won ‚Äì and lost

Collingwood were on shaky ground heading into the finals series with five defeats in their last seven matches on the run home, including a loss to Brisbane. But their spread of experienced and evergreen talent benefited from the pre-finals bye as much as any side and they outclassed and outsmarted Adelaide once the stakes rose. While the Magpies had winners all over the field in the qualifying final, it was the defence that led the way as the No 1 team for points against this year tightened the screws against the minor premiers. The Pies will hope to further strengthen their backline with the injured Jeremy Howe nearing a return in time to face the Lions.

  • During finals sign up for our free weekly AFL newsletter

The Magpies are the top-ranked side for tackles with an average 65.3 as well as tackle differential (+13.2), and second-highest for tackles inside 50 at 12.7 a game. For some teams the high number of tackles might be a pointer to the opposition having their hands on the ball more often, but for the Pies it is a reminder that their miserly defence begins with a combativeness at the contest and being the best team in the competition for pressure all over the field. Even with a side packed with players aged on the high side of 30, the Magpies are likely to hit the ground fresh and full of running in what will be just their second game in 29 days.

Brisbane will have to take the long route to reach the grand final but showed last year that they can overcome that hurdle with four straight finals victories on the way to premiership glory. A return to the MCG should hold few fears for the Lions who won five in a row at the venue before a surprisingly lacklustre display in the qualifying final defeat to Geelong. The reigning premiers bounced back the following week ‚Äì as they have so often done after a defeat this year ‚Äì to thump bitter rivals Gold Coast with a reminder of how freely they can score when their midfield and forward line click.

The Lions will miss the injured Lachie Neale for a second week in a row but showed in the resounding win over the Suns that they have enough depth to still compete with ‚Äì and even overpower ‚Äì the strongest onball brigades. The reigning premiers are the best of the remaining four teams for clearances with an average of 40.4 a game, as well as for clearance differential (+4.7), and built their victory at the coalface with 51-34 clearances the last time they took on the Magpies.

Game shapers

Collingwood: Steele Sidebottom ‚Äì the Magpies veteran was considering retirement at times last year but again looks to have plenty left in his legs as he lines up for a 28th final and ninth preliminary final. The 34-year-old has booted 15 goals and averaged 21.4 disposals this year but it is Sidebottom‚Äôs ability to make an impact when the game is on the line that continues to set him apart. The versatile midfielder broke the game open when booting three of the Pies‚Äô five goals as they snatched back the lead from the Crows and then powered away either side of the main break in a burst that set up their qualifying final win. Sidebottom might not have the pace that he once did but the player who booted the Magpies‚Äô last goal in the 2023 grand final victory over the Lions has more than enough class and composure to remain a match-turning threat.

Brisbane: Cam Rayner ‚Äì the Lions dynamo has become a September specialist as he rises to the occasion in finals whether settling forward or mixing in bursts in the midfield. Rayner came under fire for the way he went to ground easily to earn a pair of contentious free kicks during the qualifying loss to Geelong but responded in the best possible way against Gold Coast with his brute force on full display. The 25-year-old shrugged off eight Suns tackles during the semi-final including stepping out of one before launching a long bomb to goal from barely in front of the centre circle. When Rayner plays well, the Lions tend to win, making the prospect of a match-up with rugged Pies defender Brayden Maynard likely to be pivotal to the result ‚Äì and mouth-watering for fans.

Early prediction

Collingwood need no reminder of the threat that Brisbane pose when they are at their best but can turn to refreshed veterans to edge the reigning premiers in another finals classic.

title: Birth control: why are influencers turning away from the pill and towards natural contraceptive methods? | Antiviral
description:
Claims on social media feeds are that synthetic hormones cause infertility and affect romantic choices. Experts say unintended pregnancies have reached ‚Äòconcerning levels‚Äô

  • Read more in the Antiviral series
content:
In the 1960s it was considered a watershed moment of liberation for women. Now, a new generation is being inundated with messages online that birth control is ‚Äúevil‚Äù and ‚Äúpoison‚Äù. Across social media feeds, influencers are venting about hormonal contraception. Some are spreading false claims that taking synthetic hormones causes infertility, or can even be responsible for bad romantic decisions because you are ‚Äúattracted to different men than you would be if you were off the pill‚Äù. Others emphasise known side-effects, such as weight gain and depression.

Meanwhile, millions of TikToks promote the effectiveness of natural contraceptive methods, with self-described ‚Äúhormone experts‚Äù claiming it is ‚Äúnot that hard to prevent pregnancy naturally‚Äù with fertility awareness methods ‚Äújust as effective, if not more effective than the birth control pill.‚Äù

Experts such as Dr Sarah White, the CEO of Jean Hailes for Women‚Äôs Health, say the ‚Äúmisinformation is extraordinary‚Äù and are seriously concerned about the potential consequences for women.

What is this trend?

Researchers at La Trobe University analysed 100 TikTok videos from the top five hashtags related to contraception methods (#birthcontrol, #contraception, #thepill, #naturalbirthcontrol, and #cycletracking) that had collectively gained nearly 5bn views and 14.6m likes.

They found that more than half of the video creators (53%) explicitly rejected hormonal birth control, and more than one in three (34%) expressed a distrust about healthcare professionals. Meanwhile, 38% endorsed fertility tracking, often without disclosing the limitations of this method.

Related: A meaty topic: what is the carnivore diet and why do so many influencers seem to swear by it? | Antiviral

White says the popularity of this kind of material is being driven by a number of factors: a wellness industry that often encourages women to not put anything unnatural in their bodies, a younger generation of women being increasingly sceptical of their doctors pushing pharmaceuticals, and a social media environment that rewards inflammatory statements and fear-based messaging. There is also a conservative backlash against birth control.

Do ‚Äònatural‚Äô contraceptive methods work?

Fertility awareness-based contraceptive methods aim to identify the fertile window by tracking biomarkers for ovulation, such as basal body temperature and cervical mucus, to avoid a pregnancy. The method can be up to 99% effective when used correctly, but when it isn‚Äôt, almost one in four users will get pregnant over a year, according to the UK‚Äôs National Health Service.

Prof Danielle Mazza, a practising GP and the head of Monash University‚Äôs department of general practice, says many women find it hard to determine when the fertile period of their cycle actually is. She says basal body temperature tracking is not a good way to prevent pregnancy.

Even for women who have a very regular cycle and feel confident identifying their fertile window, the method still relies on several additional factors to work, she says. They have to be prepared to forego sex for considerable periods of time during the month, as well as spontaneity in their sex lives. They also have to have a partner who‚Äôs not coercive or violent, and they must make sure they don‚Äôt have sex when they‚Äôre inebriated or under the influence, Mazza says.

What about side effects of hormonal contraception?

Hormonal contraception is one of the most researched medications, Mazza says. ‚ÄúThe majority of women can use these forms of medication very happily, with very few side-effects.‚Äù

Known side-effects of hormonal birth control include headaches, nausea, mood swings, weight gain, sore breasts and acne. However, social media can amplify individual negative experiences, with research showing young people in particular often believe that a lived experience is just as credible as advice from a trained professional, White says.

If women are unhappy with the side-effects they are experiencing, Mazza encourages them to talk to their doctor rather than discarding contraception, because there are different methods of effective contraception that could suit them better. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs very important to come back for review, because also a lot of women can attribute symptoms to the pill or other hormonal forms of contraception, whereas there might be other reasons why they‚Äôre getting those kinds of symptoms.‚Äù

Mazza also highlights that some side-effects can be transient. For example, breast tenderness or feelings of fullness when you start the pill are common, but usually subside within a few months. She says she does not know of any research to prove claims that women are attracted to men they wouldn‚Äôt be attracted to if they were off the pill.

What do experts recommend?

Dr Caroline de Moel-Mandel, the lead author of the La Trobe University study and a GP, says women often feel they aren‚Äôt listened to in clinical settings. As a result, if they feel pressed into accepting a particular contraceptive method, they might search for an alternative or talk about it and seek validation online from women who feel the same way, ‚Äúand it becomes a cycle‚Äù.

‚ÄúThe platform offers women a space to talk about their side-effects, or their distrust or their frustrations that they have with the pill, or maybe even with the consultations that they had with their doctors,‚Äù Moel-Mandel says.

‚ÄúWomen need to be part of that decision-making process,‚Äù with their own lived experience being validated alongside their doctor‚Äôs medical perspective, she says. Other barriers, such as appointments being too expensive, also need to be addressed.

White also emphasises that data shows ‚Äì at least in the Australian context ‚Äì that the level of knowledge around contraception is very low. Many women are worried about short- and long-term side-effects of hormonal contraception. As a result, she says, there is ‚Äúa concerning level of unintended pregnancy‚Äù.

‚ÄúBeing able to choose when to get pregnant is really, really, really critical for a woman‚Äôs health and her economic security.‚Äù But White stresses that ‚Äúyou can‚Äôt make an informed choice if you‚Äôre being misled.‚Äù

‚Ä¢ Natasha May is Guardian Australia‚Äôs health reporter

‚Ä¢ Antiviral is a fortnightly column that interrogates the evidence behind the health headlines and factchecks popular wellness claims
